*  **Television:** Television access [12] and viewing frequency were also part of the study. ![{Television access frequency}](image6)
*   **Newspaper:** The survey included data on newspaper access [5] and readership. ![{Newspaper access frequency}](image4)
*   **Internet:** Internet access [6] and usage were investigated. ![{Internet access frequency}](image7)

The media sources surveyed in the report are radio, television, newspapers, and the Internet.

The survey methodology involved a multistage sampling technique to ensure a representative sample of the national population. [1] Wave III of the survey included 4,021 respondents.
![Wave III sample size](image7)
The gender distribution of the sample closely mirrored the national census data. [12]
![Gender distribution of respondents in September 2014](image4)
It shows that 49.8% of the respondents were female in September 2014, and as the fieldwork for Wave III took place from August 29 to September 29, 2014. [7]
We can find the radio listening habits.
![Radio listening habits by gender](image1)
It indicates that 55.7% of female respondents reported never listening to the radio in the past six months.

To find the number of female respondents in Wave III who never listened to the radio, we calculate:
4,021 (total respondents in Wave III) * 0.498 (proportion of female) * 0.557 (proportion of female who never listen to radio) = 1111.35

Therefore, approximately 1111 female respondents in Wave III never listened to the radio in the recent half year.

Among Hispanic origin groups in the United States, Cubans exhibit the strongest inclination towards Republican candidates and express the most support for Donald Trump's potential 2024 presidential bid.

Cuban registered voters are more likely to vote for a Republican candidate (55%) than other Latino groups.
![Hispanic origin groups voting preference](image3)

Also, About a quarter of Cuban voters say Trump should run for president in 2024 [3], with 29% saying they would like to see Trump as a major national figure.
![Percentage of Latino voters who would like to see Trump as a major figure](image8)

In conclusion, Cuban Americans are the most likely Hispanic origin group to vote for a Republican candidate for the U.S. House and to support a Trump presidential run in 2024.

From 2008 to 2016, Republican voters have maintained a consistent preference for a more conservative direction, while Democratic voters have shown a growing preference for a more liberal approach.

Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently preferred the GOP to move in a more conservative direction rather than a moderate one [9]. In November 2016, 60% favored a conservative shift, while 36% preferred more moderation, a distribution similar to previous years [8, 9].
![Republican voters' preference for party direction from 2008 to 2016](image4)

In contrast, Democratic voters have become more supportive of a liberal shift [11]. In November 2016, 49% of Democratic and Democratic-leaning voters wanted their party to move in a more liberal direction, while 47% favored a more moderate approach [4, 11]. This marks a notable increase from 2008 and 2012, when majorities preferred a more moderate direction (57% in both years) [5, 11].
![Democratic voters' preference for party direction from 2008 to 2016](image8)

In summary, Republican voters' preference stayed consistently conservative, while Democratic voters showed an increased desire for more liberal policies from 2008 to 2016.

Voter opinions on appointing opposition party members differed significantly between Trump in 2016 and Obama in 2008. In 2008, 52% of Obama voters believed he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet [10]. In contrast, only 26% of Trump voters in 2016 thought he should appoint Democrats to serve in his administration [7].

The data indicates a shift in voter sentiment regarding cross-party appointments. A significant portion of Trump voters (52%) indicated that it doesn't matter if Trump appoints Democrats [7], and another 21% said Trump should not name Democrats to his cabinet, while ![Voter opinions on appointing opposition party members between Trump and Obama.](image8) shows that, in November 2016, the percentage of Trump voters who think he should not appoint democrats is almost the same as those who think he should.

In summary, voter sentiment regarding the appointment of opposition party members differed greatly between Trump and Obama, with a much smaller percentage of Trump voters favoring such appointments compared to Obama voters in 2008.

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS shifted between July and December 2015. While the overall approval of the military campaign remained steady [11], there was a notable increase in the belief that the U.S. and its allies would succeed. In July 2015, 55% believed the U.S. would definitely or probably succeed, and this number increased to 66% in December 2015 [6].

This shift is visualized in a bar graph:
![Perception of success in the military campaign against ISIS increased from July to December 2015.](image5)

Furthermore, ratings of how well the military effort was going remained negative [2], with a fairly stable percentage of respondents between those months rating the campaign as going "Not too/at all well" (62% in July and 58% in December).
![From July to December 2015 public perception of how well the military effort was going was negative](image6)

In summary, perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS became more optimistic from July to December 2015, with a significant rise in the belief that the campaign would be successful, even though evaluation of the campaign's progress remained largely negative.

Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence more than other religions have become increasingly polarized along political lines, with a significant partisan divide [6, 11].

Overall, the percentage of Americans who believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence has fluctuated but remains divided. In 2015, 46% believed Islam was more likely to encourage violence, down from a high of 50% in 2014 [7].
![Public opinion on Islam and violence over time](image4)
The share of the public saying that Islam is more likely than other religions to encourage violence has dropped four percentage points since a historical high of $50\%$ in September 2014 [7].

A significant partisan gap exists. In 2015, 68% of Republicans believed Islam encourages violence more than other religions, which was a historical high at that time but relatively unchanged from the previous fall [1, 11].
![Islam and violence views from 2002-2015 by political party](image2)
In contrast, only 30% of Democrats held the same view, down from 42% in September 2014 [1, 11]. This partisan divide is the widest it has ever been [11].

Ideological differences are stark, with 77% of conservative Republicans saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence, compared to only 16% who say it does not. Among liberal Democrats, 73% say Islam is no more likely to encourage violence [4]. The share of liberals saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence dropped by 14 points since the fall of 2014 [10].

In summary, Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have become more politically polarized over time, with a substantial and growing gap between Republicans and Democrats.

Americans generally view the concept of machines performing jobs currently done by humans with more worry than enthusiasm.

A significant majority (85%) of Americans have heard or read about the concept of automation impacting employment [2], and 77% consider the idea at least somewhat realistic [2], with 20% finding it extremely realistic [8].

However, when asked about a future where robots and computers could perform many human jobs, 72% of Americans expressed worry, compared to only 33% who expressed enthusiasm [1]. This concern is further highlighted by the fact that Americans are three times more likely to express worry (67%) than enthusiasm (22%) about algorithms making hiring decisions without human involvement [1].
![image8](image8)

The level of awareness about this concept also influences perception.  Almost half (48%) of Americans who have heard a lot about machines potentially performing many human jobs find the concept extremely realistic [12].
![image6](image6)

And although they view certain jobs as being more at risk than others, a significant majority of todays workers express little concern that their own jobs or careers might be performed by machines in their lifetimes. [6]

In summary, while most Americans acknowledge the potential for machines to perform many human jobs, they predominantly view this prospect with concern rather than optimism.

Americans express a range of opinions regarding limiting machine use in the workforce and the replacement of human jobs with automation. A majority (58%) believe there should be limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines [1].
![image8](image8)

A smaller percentage (41%) think that businesses are justified in replacing humans with machines if they can achieve better work at a lower cost [1].
![image1](image1)

There's also strong support (85%) for limiting machines to performing jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [6]. Other policy solutions, such as a universal basic income or a national service program for displaced workers, receive favorable responses, though with less intensity than the support for limiting machines to hazardous jobs [9].

In conclusion, the majority of the public opinion supports limiting machine use in the workforce, especially for jobs that are not dangerous or unhealthy for humans.

Perceptions of job availability are divided along partisan lines, with majorities of both Republicans and Democrats believing there are plenty of jobs available locally [12]. Republicans are more optimistic, with 71% saying there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [2].

This partisan gap is visually represented in a graph.
![Perceptions of job availability rise in both parties, especially the GOP](image4)

The specific breakdown of these views is also presented in a table format:
![Job availiability between Republicans and Democrats](image6)

In summary, while both majorities of Republicans and Democrats believe jobs are available, Republicans are significantly more likely to hold this view.

The Pew Research Center survey highlights several major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs. These reasons are rooted in educational opportunities, societal perceptions, and workplace discrimination.

Key factors contributing to this underrepresentation include:

*   **Lack of Encouragement:** Many Americans believe that a lack of encouragement for girls, blacks, and Hispanics to pursue STEM from an early age is a significant factor [1]. Specifically, 39% of Americans see this as a major reason for the lack of women in certain STEM areas, and 41% say it is a major reason for the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in the STEM workforce [1].
*   **Limited Access to Quality Education:** Limited access to quality education is another frequently cited reason [3]. About half of STEM workers believe this is a major reason why blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented [3].
     -   This view is particularly strong among black STEM workers (73%) and is also held by about half of Hispanics (53%), Asians (52%), and whites (50%) in STEM jobs [11].
*    **Discrimination**:
    *   **Perceived Discrimination**: There is significant disagreement across racial and ethnic groups regarding how much discrimination contributes to these disparities [4]. Among STEM workers, 72% of blacks believe that discrimination in recruiting, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the underrepresentation, compared to only 27% of whites and 28% of Asians [4].
 *   **Workplace Experiences**: Black STEM workers are especially likely to report experiencing discrimination at work due to their race or ethnicity [2]. 62% of blacks in STEM report such experiences, compared to 44% of Asians, 42% of Hispanics, and only 13% of whites [2].

* **Major reasons**:
    *    Major reasons for underrepresentation include limited access to quality education, discrimination in recruitment and promotions, and lack of encouragement from an early age [5].

![Major reason more women are not in STEM jobs](image5)

In summary, the major reasons for the underrepresentation of women, blacks, and Hispanics in STEM jobs, according to the Pew Research Center, are a lack of early encouragement, limited access to quality education, and discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions.

Americans, in general, are critical of the quality of STEM education in K-12 schools, with a quarter viewing it as above average compared to other developed countries [9, 10]. However, there's a significant difference in perception among those with a postgraduate degree in a STEM field.

A much smaller percentage (13%) of STEM postgraduate degree holders rate K-12 STEM education as above average [4, 11].  About half (51%) of this group believes the U.S. is *below average* in this regard [11]. This contrasts with the 27% of adults with some college or less education who give K-12 STEM education the same rating [11].

This difference is further illustrated by the visual data:

![Perceptions of K-12 STEM education](image4)

The data indicates that individuals with a STEM postgraduate degree view K-12 public schools as below average.

In summary, STEM postgraduate degree holders have a significantly more negative perception of K-12 STEM education in the U.S. compared to the general adult population.

The document describes confidence and likelihood language to express uncertainty [9]. Confidence reflects the validity of a finding, based on evidence (type, amount, quality, strength, and consistency) and expert agreement, ranging qualitatively from low to very high [9]. ![Confidence Level](image8) Author teams determine confidence levels by assessing available literature, evidence quality/quantity, and agreement across studies [11].

Likelihood language, on the other hand, describes the probability of an occurrence, using statistical analysis or expert judgment [2]. ![Likelihood](image4) It provides a quantitative estimate of uncertainty, with terms ranging from "very unlikely" ( 1 in 10 chance) to "very likely" ( 9 in 10 chance) [3]. All Key Findings include a confidence description, and where scientifically justified, a likelihood designation [11].

In summary, confidence levels are evaluated based on the quality and consensus of evidence, while likelihood is evaluated using probabilistic measures of uncertainty.

Americans have similar views of the Republican and Democratic parties regarding their policy ideas and ethical standards. However, more people view the Republican Party as "too extreme" compared to the Democratic Party [12].

Specifically, on ethical standards, 41% of Americans believe the GOP has high ethical standards, while 42% say the same about the Democratic Party [4]. ![A comparison of public perception on political parties' policy ideas, ethical standards, and extremism.](image1)

However, these perceptions differ significantly among various educational and political affiliation groups:

*   **Educational Groups**: Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" describes neither the GOP nor the Democratic Party. This is compared to 26% of those with some college education and 20% of those with a high school education or less. [10, ]![Perceptions of party ethics based on different groups.](image4)
*   **Political Affiliation**: Independents are more likely (34%) than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards [5]. In contrast, only 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats say this.![Perceptions of party ethics based on different groups.](image4) Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards [9].

In summary, while the general public has similar views on both parties' ethical standards, more people perceive the Republican Party as "too extreme." Perceptions of the parties' ethics vary significantly by educational level and political affiliation, with college-educated individuals and independents being more critical of both parties' ethical standards.

Americans view the ethical standards of the Republican and Democratic parties similarly, with 41% saying the GOP has high ethical standards and 42% saying the same about the Democratic Party [1, 4]. This is visually represented in a bar graph showing the nearly identical ratings for both parties on ethical standards.
![A bar graph showing public perception of both parties.](image1)
However, perceptions of extremism differ, with more people viewing the Republican Party as "too extreme" (48%) compared to the Democratic Party (42%) [7, 10].

These perceptions are influenced by both education and political affiliation:

*   **Education**: A quarter of the public believes that neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party has "high ethical standards"[6]. A more granular breakdown indicates 31% of those with at least a college degree say neither party has high ethical standards [3, 12]. In comparison, fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [12].
![A bar graph of ethical standard perception by education level](image4)
*   **Political Affiliation**: Partisans are more likely to view their own party positively. Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards [8]. Independents are significantly more likely to say neither party has high ethical standards [5].
![Perception of own party's feeling by political affiliation.](image2)

In conclusion, while the public views both parties similarly on ethical standards, the Republican Party is seen as more extreme, with education and political affiliation significantly influencing these perceptions.

Americans have similar views of both the Republican and Democratic parties regarding their policy ideas and ethical standards [2]. However, perceptions vary significantly across education levels and political affiliations.

A quarter of the public believes that neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party has "high ethical standards," while 47% say it describes one party but not the other, and 17% believe it applies to both [7].
![A chart showing how different groups of people feel about the ethical standards of major political parties.](image5)
Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has "high ethical standards" [9]. About a third of independents (34%) believe neither party has high ethical standards, compared to only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) [9].

Educational differences are notable in these perceptions.
*   Among those with at least a college degree, 31% say "high ethical standards" does not describe either party [10].
*    Fewer of those with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less education (20%) think neither party has high ethical standards [12].
*   Nearly a third of college graduates say neither party has 'high ethical standards' [5].

In terms of political party preferences, there are also sizable educational differences in early midterm vote preferences:
![A chart showing voting preference for different groups.](image3)
*   Voters with a postgraduate degree favor the Democratic candidate over the Republican by roughly two-to-one (62% to 30%) [8].
*   Those with a four-year college degree also favor the Democrat, 53% to 40% [8].
*    Preferences are more divided among voters who do not have a college degree [8].
*   Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards [6].

In summary, a significant portion of the American public, especially independents and those with higher education, are skeptical of the ethical standards of both major political parties, and educational attainment significantly influences voter preferences, with higher education levels correlating with a stronger preference for Democratic candidates.

Public perception of Trump's handling of economic policy is more positive than the perception of his ethical standards, with a notable partisan divide in both areas.

A majority of Americans (53%) express at least some confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions about economic policy [6, 12]. This confidence has slightly increased since January [12].
![Public confidence in Trump on various issues, including economic policy](image1)

However, views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are significantly lower and sharply divided along party lines. While 75% of Republicans rate the administration's ethical standards as good or excellent, 86% of Democrats rate them as not good or poor [9].
![Views on ethical standards of Trump administration officials, by party](image8)
Overall, 39% say that ethical standards are good or excellent, will 58% of total responses are poor or not good [9].
There are internal divisions even within the Republican Party regarding Trump's conduct, with only 38% expressing approval and 45% having mixed feelings. [3, 5].

In summary, while a slim majority expresses confidence in Trump's economic policy decisions, a larger portion of the public, particularly Democrats, view the ethical standards of his administration negatively.

Public opinion on Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has shown some positive change over time, with increasing confidence in both areas.

Specifically, regarding economic policy, public confidence in Trump's handling has "ticked up" since January [10]. The data shows that 53% express at least some confidence in his ability to make good decisions about economic policy [7], with a breakdown of confidence levels illustrated in the following chart:

![Public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy is 53%](image1)

For international crises, 43% of the public expresses confidence in Trump's ability to handle such situations, which is an increase from 35% in January [12]. The change over time, along with other key issues, can be seen in this image:

![Changes in public confidence in Trump's handling of key issues, including international crises and economic policy.](image3)

Partisan perspectives reveal significant differences. Republicans have grown "significantly more confident" in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis, with 84% expressing confidence, compared to 73% in January [9]. Overall, 80% of Republicans and Republican-leaners agree with Trump on many or all issues [3].

In contrast, Democrats overwhelmingly do not like the way Trump conducts himself (85%) [8].

In summary, public confidence in Trump's ability to handle both economic policy and international crises has increased, driven largely by a rise in confidence among Republicans, while Democratic views remain overwhelmingly negative.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle economic policy and international crises has generally increased.

  In May 2018, 53% of the public expressed at least some confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions about economic policy, up from 46% in January 2018 [9]. Confidence in his ability to handle an international crisis also rose, from 35% in January 2018 to 43% in May 2018 [4, 6].
![Public confidence in Trumps ability to handle an international crisis and make good decisions about economic policy increased from January to May 2018.](image2)

These shifts align with increasing agreement among Republicans regarding Trump's policies. 80% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents reported agreeing with Trump on many or all issues in May 2018, an increase of 11 percentage points since August 2017 [10].
![In May 2018, 80% of Republicans agreed with Trump on many or all issues.](image1)

However, there's a stark contrast between Republican and Democrat views on Trump's conduct. While 38% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents said they liked the way Trump conducted himself as president in the survey [2], 85% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents reported disliking his conduct [8].
![In May 2018, 38% of Republicans liked Trumps conduct, while 85% of Democrats did not.](image5)

In summary, public confidence in Trump's handling of economic policy and international crises has ticked up, driven largely by increasing confidence among Republicans, while Democrats remain overwhelmingly negative about his conduct.

Public confidence in Trump's handling of both international crises and economic policy has increased since January. [10, 11, 12]

Specifically, 43% of the public express confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis, which is an increase from 35% in January. [11]
![Public confidence in Trump's ability to handle an international crisis over time.](image8)

In terms of economic policy, 53% of the public now expresses confidence in Trump's handling, compared to 46% in January. [12]
![Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good decisions about economic policy over time.](image8)

More people are confident in trump's ability on economic policy than international crisis.

There are notable differences and shifts in opinions among Republicans and Democrats regarding Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration.

Democrats consistently express strong disapproval of Trump's conduct. A significant majority (85%) say they don't like the way he conducts himself in office [4]. This view is further emphasized by the data showing that 88% of Democrats and Democratic leaners disapprove, with 71% disapproving strongly.
![Democrats and Democratic leaners' disapproval of Trump's conduct.](image5)
Within the Republican party, opinions are more divided. While 38% of Republicans and Republican leaners say they like the way Trump conducts himself, a substantial 45% report having "mixed feelings," and 16% dislike his conduct [9].
![Republicans and Republican leaners show mixed feelings about Trump's conduct.](image6)
This division is also apparent in the assessment of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials.

In terms of changes over time, the data indicates a growing agreement among Republicans with Trump on issues. 80% of Republicans and Republican-leaners agree with Trump on many or all issues, marking an 11% increase since August [12].
![Change of Agreement with Trump on issues between Republicans and Democrats.](image2)
However, when considering the ethical standards, a clear partisan divide is shown: 75% of Republicans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as "Excellent" or "Good", while 86% of Democrats rate them as "Poor" or "Not good".
![Ethical standards of Trump administration officials show a partisan divide.](image3)

In conclusion, Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct and the ethical standards of his administration, while Republicans show more varied opinions, with a significant portion having mixed feelings or expressing disapproval, despite increasing agreement on policy issues.

Public evaluations of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are lower than those of past administrations. [2, 11]

A May 2018 survey shows that 39% of Americans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor. ![A May 2018 survey shows that 39% of Americans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 58% rate them as not good or poor.](image3) This contrasts with higher ratings for past administrations, such as Ronald Reagan's in 1983. [11] For example, the ethical standards rating for Trump in May 2018 was 39, noticeably lower than Obama's 49 in June 2013, and significantly lower than figures like Bush's 59 in May 1989 or Reagan's 67 in October 1984. ![The ethical standards rating for Trump in May 2018 was 39, noticeably lower than Obama's 49 in June 2013, and significantly lower than figures like Bush's 59 in May 1989 or Reagan's 67 in October 1984.](image7)

There's a strong partisan divide in these views. 75% of Republicans rate the ethical standards of key administration members as good or excellent, whereas 86% of Democrats rate them as not good or poor. [12] This partisan divide is also reflected in the intensity of disapproval. ![This partisan divide is also reflected in the intensity of disapproval.](image8)

The public's evaluation of Donald Trump's job performance has remained relatively stable, with a significant portion of the public disapproving very strongly. [3, 4]
There is an 18-point gender gap in approval ratings of the president, 48% of men approve of Trumps performance, while just 30% of women say the same. [6]
Overall, the approval of Trump's handling of specific issues varies, with economic policy and trade agreements receiving relatively higher confidence.
![Overall, the approval of Trump's handling of specific issues varies, with economic policy and trade agreements receiving relatively higher confidence.](image1)

In summary, approval ratings for the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are lower compared to past administrations, and this is linked to a generally stable but deeply divided public approval of Trump's overall job performance.

Americans' perceptions of ethical standards in politics, as well as their approval ratings of Donald Trump, are significantly influenced by their educational levels and political affiliations.

In terms of ethical standards of the two major political parties, a quarter of the public believes that neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party has high ethical standards [5]. However, this perception varies significantly based on educational attainment. College graduates are more likely to believe neither party has high standards.
![Perceptions of ethical standards by educational level.](image6)
Specifically, 31% of those with at least a college degree say "high ethical standards" does not describe either party [12], compared to 26% of those with some college experience and 20% of those with a high school degree or less [4].

Political affiliation also plays a crucial role. Independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has high ethical standards [9].
![Party ethics by political affiliation.](image6)
About a third of independents (34%) hold this view, with equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners (33% each) agreeing. In contrast, only about two-in-ten Republicans (19%) or Democrats (18%) say the same [9]. Majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards [1].

Regarding Trump's approval ratings, there are notable differences based on education and political affiliation.
![Approval ratings by demographic groups.](image1)
As the image shows, individuals with higher levels of education are more likely to disapprove of Trump's job performance [2]. Postgraduates show the highest disapproval rate at 68%, followed by college graduates at 62% [image1]. Approval is higher among those with some college (41% approve) or a high school diploma or less (43% approve) [image1].

Politically, Republicans and Republican-leaning independents overwhelmingly approve of Trump, while Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents largely disapprove [image1, image3].
![Approval ratings by political affiliation.](image3)
Among Republicans and leaners, 81% approve of Trump, and 88% of Democrats and leaners disapprove [image1].

In summary, higher education levels correlate with greater skepticism about the ethical standards of both political parties, and with higher disapproval of Donald Trump. Political affiliation is a strong predictor of both ethical perceptions and approval ratings, with partisans mostly approving of their own party and independents more likely to be critical of both.

Voter reactions to the 2016 presidential election were mixed, with a significant portion expressing negative emotions. Half of the voters were happy that Donald Trump won the election, while nearly as many (48%) were unhappy [6]. Reactions were similar to the 2012 election but less positive than after Obama's first election in 2008 [2].

A significant majority of voters (73%) were surprised by Trump's victory, including 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters [3].

![A majority of voters were surprised by the outcome of the 2016 presidential election.](image8)

Many voters reported feeling uneasy (53%) about Trump's election.
![Many voters say they feel uneasy about the election of Trump](image2)

However, a slight majority (51%) also felt hopeful [9]. Reactions among Trump and Clinton voters were starkly different.
![Emotional reactions to Trumps election among Trump voters and Clinton voters.](image3)

The 2016 campaign was perceived as more negative and less issue-focused than past elections [5].

In summary, voter reactions to the 2016 election were mixed, with a high level of surprise and a significant degree of negative emotions, including uneasiness, alongside some hopefulness.

Emotional reactions to Trump's election significantly differed between Trump and Clinton voters, as did their expectations for his first term.

Trump voters overwhelmingly expressed positive emotions.  Nearly all Trump supporters (96%) said his election made them feel hopeful, and a large majority (74%) felt proud [3, 7]. This positivity was reflected in their expectations, with 97% of Trump voters expecting him to have a successful first term [6]. ![A comparison of voter expectations for Trump's and Obama's first terms, showing higher expectations among Trump voters than Clinton voters.](image1)

Conversely, Clinton voters reported predominantly negative emotions.  Large majorities felt uneasy (90%), sad (77%), and scared (76%) about Trump's victory [7, 12].  A majority (62%) also felt angry [12]. ![Breakdown of emotional responses to Trump's election among Clinton voters.](image5) These negative feelings corresponded with low expectations for Trump's first term. Only 15% of Clinton supporters believed Trump would have a successful first term, while 76% expected it to be unsuccessful [9]. This is significantly lower than the 39% of McCain supporters in 2008 who expected Obama to have a successful first term [9].

In summary, Trump voters reacted to his election with hope and pride, anticipating a successful first term, while Clinton voters reacted with unease, sadness, and fear, expecting an unsuccessful term.

Voters are deeply polarized in their reactions to Trumps victory and expectations for his presidency [6].

A vast majority (97%) of Trump voters expect him to have a successful first term, which is comparable to the 92% of Obama voters who said this about their candidate in 2008 [9]. ![Among winning candidates voters](image8)

On the other hand, only 15% of Clinton supporters think Trumps first term will be successful, while 76% think it will be unsuccessful [10]. In 2008, nearly four-in-ten McCain supporters (39%) thought Obama would have a successful first term [10].

![Among losing candidates voters](image8)

However, 58% of Clinton voters say they are willing to give Trump a chance and see how he governs as president [1, 11].
![Willing to give Trump a chance to see how he governs](image3)

Nearly four-in-ten (39%) Clinton voters say they cant see themselves giving Trump a chance because of the kind of person he has shown himself to be [1, 11].
![Cant see myself giving Trump a chance because of kind of person he has shown himself to be](image3)

In summary, while the vast majority of Trump voters are optimistic about his success, the majority of Clinton voters are pessimistic, though a majority are willing to give him a chance.

Voters had different ideas about what Trump's first priority should be as president [5].

Health care was the most frequently mentioned priority, suggested by 20% of all voters [5]. However, this differed significantly between voter groups: 29% of Trump voters named health care as the top priority, compared to only 12% of Clinton voters [9].
![image5](image5)
The economy, immigration, unifying the country, and jobs/unemployment were also among the top priorities, but with varying levels of importance between the two groups [5]. Trump voters were more likely than Clinton voters to prioritize the economy (15% vs. 9%) and immigration (15% vs. 6%) [10].

Clinton voters placed a greater emphasis on healing divisions. About a quarter (23%) of Clinton voters suggested that Trump should prioritize unifying the country (12%) or changing his personal behavior and addressing divisions created during the campaign (11%) [6].
![image7](image7)
These differing priorities suggest that Trump voters are more focused on specific policy issues like healthcare, the economy, and immigration, while Clinton voters are more concerned with Trump's leadership style and his ability to unite the country.

Furthermore, a large majority of Clinton voters (84%) stated that Trump's goals were not very clear to them [8].
![image4](image4)

In Summary, The priorities for Trump's presidency differed significantly between Trump and Clinton voters, with Trump voters focusing on policy issues and Clinton voters emphasizing leadership style and national unity.

Trump and Clinton voters held significantly different views on Trump's capability to handle foreign policy and had contrasting expectations for race relations following his election.

Regarding foreign policy, a large majority of Clinton voters expressed little to no confidence in Trump's abilities. Nearly two-thirds (63%) reported having *no confidence at all* in Trump's handling of foreign policy [9]. In stark contrast, a significant portion of Trump voters (47%) expressed "a great deal" of confidence in his foreign policy approach, with another 44% having "a fair amount" of confidence [1], [!["A great deal" and "a fair amount" confidence of Trump voters and Clinton voters on different issues.](image7)].
![Confidence levels in Trump's handling of various issues, including foreign policy.](image5)

On the issue of race relations, the divide was equally pronounced.  A substantial 84% of Clinton voters anticipated that race relations would worsen under Trump's presidency [11], [!["Better", "No difference" and "worse" race relation under Trump's election.](image6)]. Conversely, half of Trump voters (50%) expected race relations to improve [7].

In summary, Clinton voters overwhelmingly lacked confidence in Trump's foreign policy capabilities and expected a deterioration in race relations, while Trump voters generally expressed confidence in his foreign policy and anticipated improvements in race relations.

The survey data reveals significant differences between Trump and Clinton voters' confidence in Trump's ability to improve race relations and political cooperation.

Regarding race relations, a substantial portion of Trump voters (50%) expect improvements, while a much smaller percentage (9%) anticipate a worsening of the situation [10]. Conversely, an overwhelming majority of Clinton voters (84%) believe Trump's election will lead to worse race relations [4]. This stark contrast is visually represented in a chart, which shows the breakdown of voter expectations:  ![Voters' expectations on the impact of Trump's election on race relations.](image8)

In 2008, a greater number of voters (52%) were optimistic about Obama, expecting him to improve race relations [7].

Turning to political cooperation, or "partisan relations," nearly half of Trump voters (47%) expect improvement, compared to only 9% who predict a decline [9]. A comparison chart clearly illustrates this, showing that Clinton voters are far more pessimistic: ![Comparison of voters' expectation on how will partisan relations change after Trump's and Obama's election.](image6)

This is showing that 43% of clinton voters think it will get worse, compared with a smaller 31% of Mccain voter thinking it would get worse with Obama [6].

In summary, Trump voters are significantly more optimistic than Clinton voters about Trump's ability to improve both race relations and political cooperation.

Voters' expectations for race relations after the 2016 election were more pessimistic compared to their expectations for partisan relations.

Regarding race relations, a significant portion of voters (46%) believed that race relations would worsen after Trump's election, while only 25% expected them to improve [9]. This contrasts with the expectations for partisan relations, where 27% of voters thought relations between the two parties would improve, and another 27% thought they would worsen [11].

![Expectations for race relations after Trump's election in 2016.](image5)

The data indicates a clear divide in expectations based on who voters supported in the election [9].
*   **Trump Voters:** Half of Trump voters (50%) expected race relations to improve, 38% thought there would be no difference, and only 9% expected things to worsen [7].
*   **Clinton Voters:** A large majority of Clinton voters (84%) expected race relations to worsen, with only 2% believing they would improve [2].

![Voter sentiment broken down by candidate support.](image6)

In 2008, after Obama's election, the voter had more optimistic, 52% said his election would lead to improve race relations [3].

Regarding the perceived implications of having enthusiastic supporters for a president, the data suggests that a majority of voters believe it leads to less getting done.
![Implications of having enthusiastic supporters for a president.](image1)

In summary, voters in 2016 were more pessimistic about race relations than partisan relations, and many believe that strong support has negative implications.

The political orientations of Democratic and Republican voters have shifted in distinct ways over time, with these changes reflected in their reactions to the 2016 election.

Republican and Republican-leaning voters have consistently favored a more conservative direction for their party [9]. The data indicates that a majority (60%) want the party to move in a conservative direction, a preference that has remained relatively stable over the years [9].
![image1](image1)

In contrast, Democratic voters show a more divided stance, with a growing preference for a more liberal direction [10]. In November 2016, Democratic voters were almost evenly split between wanting their party to move in a more liberal (49%) or more moderate (47%) direction [10]. This represents a significant increase in the share of Democratic voters favoring a more liberal stance compared to previous years [10].
![image2](image2)

These shifts are also connected to the reactions to the 2016 election results. Voters had mixed reactions to the Republican Party maintaining control of Congress, with 52% happy and 45% unhappy [4].
![image3](image3)
There is also significant difference between voters who supported the winning candidate and voters who supported the losing candidate [5].

In summary, Republican voters consistently prefer a conservative direction, while Democratic voters are increasingly leaning towards a more liberal stance, with these preferences reflected in mixed reactions to the 2016 election outcomes.

The shift in voter expectations and sentiments between 2008 and 2016 reveals a significant change in the political climate. In 2008, after Obama's election, a substantial majority of voters, including both Democrats and Republicans, expected their party leaders to cooperate with the new president [6].

Specifically, nearly six-in-ten (59%) Republicans said GOP leaders should work with Obama [2].
![{conclusion}](image8)
In contrast, in 2016, a majority of Democrats (65%) preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump, even if it meant less getting done in Washington. Only 32% of Democrats favored working with Trump [12].
![{conclusion}](image8)

However, More than half of Republican and Republican-leaning voters (53%) say Trump should work with Democratic leaders in Congress [5]. In 2008, a majority of voters who supported Obama (52%) said he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet, twice the share of Trump backers who favor Democrats in his cabinet today [3].
There is also less discussion on issues compared with past presidential campaigns.
![{conclusion}](image1)

Voter expectations and sentiments changed significantly between 2008 and 2016, with a greater desire in 2016 for party leaders to oppose the newly elected president, particularly among Democrats.

Voters' perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity in the 2016 election are strongly related, with both showing historically negative trends. Voters gave low grades to both the Republican and Democratic parties [3]. Only about a quarter of voters gave an A or B to the Republican Party (22%) and the Democratic Party (26%) [3].

![Chart showing voter grades for political entities and campaign negativity in the 2016 election.](image4)

This negative view extends to campaign negativity. A significant majority of voters (92%) believed there was more mudslinging or negative campaigning compared to previous contests [2, 12]. This is visualized by the ascending line in the "More mudslinging" chart.

![Voter perceptions of campaign negativity in the 2016 election compared to past elections.](image1)

Voters also expressed low opinions of the press and pollsters, with only 22% and 21% respectively giving them an A or B grade [7].

In the 2016 election, voter perceptions of political entities and campaign negativity were strongly linked, with both viewed very negatively.

The 2016 election elicited starkly different emotional responses from Trump and Clinton voters. Trump voters overwhelmingly felt "happy" and "hopeful" [2, 5].  A significant number also reported feeling "surprised" [2].

![One-word descriptions of reactions to Trumps victory among Trump and Clinton voters.](image2)

Conversely, Clinton voters predominantly felt "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" [10]. They also expressed feelings of being "uneasy," "sad," and "scared" [5].

![Voters feelings about the election of Donald Trump.](image8)

These emotional reactions correlate with a generally negative perception of Trump's campaign performance. Only 30% of voters gave Trump an A or B grade for his conduct during the campaign [11].

![Grades given for campaign conduct.](image1)

Furthermore, a record-high 92% of voters believed there was more "mudslinging" or negative campaigning than in past elections, indicating a widespread perception of negativity [7].

![Voters views on the negativity of the 2016 campaign.](image6)

In summary, Trump voters reacted to the 2016 election with positive emotions like happiness and hope, while Clinton voters reacted with negative emotions such as shock and disappointment, aligning with a generally negative view of Trump's campaign conduct and the increased negativity of the election.

Voters expressed a mix of emotional reactions to Donald Trump's election. On the positive side, 51% said they felt hopeful, and 36% felt proud [9]. However, negative emotions were also prevalent, with 53% feeling uneasy, and 41% each feeling sad or scared [9].

A significant majority of both Trump and Clinton supporters expressed surprise at the election outcome [2, 3].

![Surprise levels among all voters, Trump voters, and Clinton voters.](image6)

Specifically, 73% of all voters were surprised, including 87% of Clinton voters and 60% of Trump voters [2, 3]. This shared surprise indicates that the election result defied expectations for a large portion of voters from both sides.

When asked to describe their reactions in a single word, Trump supporters most frequently used "happy," while many also mentioned "surprise" or "shock" [7].

![Word association with reaction to Donald Trump winning the Presidential Election.](image8)

Clinton voters, on the other hand, most commonly used "shocked," followed by "disappointed" and "disgusted," with some also expressing surprise or disbelief [10]. The intensity of negative emotions among Clinton voters, coupled with the high level of surprise, reflects a strong expectation that their candidate would win. While 97% of Trump voters were happy with the outcome, 93% of Clinton voters said they were unhappy. [12]

In summary, the emotional reactions reveal a stark contrast: Trump voters were predominantly happy and surprised, while Clinton voters were overwhelmingly shocked and unhappy, indicating that the election outcome significantly diverged from the expectations of both groups, but particularly those of Clinton supporters.

Voter sentiments towards Trump's victory significantly differed between Trump and Clinton voters, as did their immediate emotional responses, but both groups largely agreed on the prospect of a female president in their lifetime.

A large majority of Trump voters (97%) said they were happy he won [11], with many describing their feelings with words like "happy," "surprised," and "relieved" [10].
![Voter sentiments among Trump voters](image6)

On the other hand, the vast majority of Clinton voters (93%) stated they were unhappy with Trump's victory [11], with top responses including "shocked," "disappointed," and "disgusted" [10].
![Voter sentiments among Clinton voters](image6)
Overall, half the voters reported being happy about Trump's victory, while nearly as many (48%) were unhappy [3, 6].

However, despite these differing sentiments about the 2016 election outcome, a sizable majority of voters (79%) across both groups still expected there would be a female president in their lifetime [4].
![Expectations for a female president among all voters](image5)
There were no significant differences in these opinions between men and women, or between Clinton and Trump supporters [4].

In conclusion, while Trump and Clinton voters had starkly contrasting emotional reactions to Trump's victory, a majority of both groups believed they would see a female president in their lifetime.

Americans' ratings of the government's efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [2]. For the first time, a majority (52%) believe the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" in reducing the threat, compared to 46% who say it is doing "very or fairly well" [2].

This negative perception has grown across the political spectrum:
*   **Democrats:** 64% rate the government's performance as "at least fairly well," down from 85% in January 2015 [3].
*   **Independents:** Positive ratings dropped from 69% to 44% [3].
*   **Republicans:** Only 27% say the government is doing "very or fairly well," a decrease from 63% at the beginning of the year [3].
*    The views of conservative Republicans have changed,In January, 59% said the government was doing very well or fairly well; today, only 18% say this. [11]

The view that government policies do not go far enough has also seen changes, particularly among Republicans:

*   **Republicans:** 71% now believe anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, up from 57% in January and 38% in July 2013 [7].
*   **Democrats:** 54% now hold this view, a slight increase since January and a 16-point rise since 2013 [5].

![image2](image2)

Perceptions also vary by age group:
*   **Older Americans (50+):** A majority (57%) believe the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat [6].
*   **Younger Americans (18-29):** A slight majority (53%) say the government is doing "very or fairly well," with 46% giving a negative rating [6].
*   Overall:
![image8](image8)

![image7](image7)

In summary, public perception of government efforts against terrorism has become more negative, with a majority now believing the government is not doing well. This shift is seen across political lines, particularly among Republicans, and is more pronounced among older Americans.

Americans' perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat are influenced by age and political ideology, and these perceptions have become more negative over time.

Older Americans tend to give the government lower marks for its efforts against terrorism [1, 11]. A majority (57%) of those 50 and older say the government is not doing well, whereas a smaller percentage (46%) of those 18-29 share this view [4].
![image7](image7)
In December 2015, 58% people aged 65+ said the government's anti-terrorism effort is not too good or not good at all.

Political ideology also plays a significant role. Democrats are more likely than Republicans and Independents to give positive ratings to the governments anti-terrorism efforts [3].
![image5](image5)
There has been a significant decrease of approvement across the political spectrum since the Bush period.

However, the positive ratings have declined across all political groups since early 2015. [3]
![image2](image2)
The disapprovement rate has raised in the public.

Overall, perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have become more negative, particularly among older Americans and those with conservative or Republican political ideologies.

Americans' views on the government's performance in reducing the terrorist threat vary significantly across different age groups. Generally, older individuals tend to be more critical of the government's efforts than younger ones [3, 12].

A majority (58%) of those aged 65 and older believe the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat. The 50-64 age group hold similar negative views, with 56% giving low ratings [6].
In contrast, among the youngest age group(18-29), negative evaluation is lower( only 46%)[6].
![image2](image2)

There are clear differences how age groups view in anti-terror policies. While younger adults (18-29) are almost divided on the issue [7].
![image5](image5)

However, majorities in every other age group are more concerned about security than civil liberties, this concern is more obvious among those 65 and older (71% say this) than those 30-49 (52%)[7].
![image3](image3)

In 2015, different age groups showed varying perceptions of the government's performance in reducing the terrorist threat, with older age groups more likely to be critical, majorities in older age groups also showed more concern about security, comparing younger age group.

Americans' views on the government's anti-terrorism efforts have changed significantly over time and vary considerably across age groups and political affiliations.

Overall, public ratings of the government's efforts to reduce terrorism are at their lowest point since the September 2001 attacks [3]. For the first time, a majority (52%) believe the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" in reducing the terrorist threat, while only 46% rate the efforts as "very" or "fairly well" [3].
![Government performance ratings on reducing terrorism threat, broken down by various demographics](image1)
This represents a 26-point drop in positive ratings since January [3].

A majority of Americans (56%) are now more concerned that anti-terrorism policies have not gone far enough to protect the country, compared to 28% who believe they have gone too far in restricting civil liberties [2, 4]. This concern is more pronounced among older age groups.
![Breakdown of opinions on anti-terrorism policies, categorized by age group](image4)
Specifically, 71% of those aged 65 and older are more concerned about security, while those under 30 are split, with 43% concerned about civil liberties and 44% about security [8].

Political affiliation also significantly impacts these opinions.
![Time series data showing trends in opinion among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents](image3)
Since Edward Snowden's disclosures in 2013, both Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, but this shift has been more pronounced among Republicans [5]. Currently, 71% of Republicans express greater concern that policies do not go far enough, a 33-point increase since July 2013 [5]. While a majority of Democrats (54%) also share this concern, the increase has been smaller, at 16 points since 2013 [11].
![Changes in opinion on various global threats between August 2014 and December 2015](image5)
Moreover, there has been a significant change view ISIS as a major threat to the U.S., that is increased by 16 points since August 2014.[9].

In summary, a majority of Americans, particularly older individuals and Republicans, believe the government's anti-terrorism efforts have not gone far enough, reflecting a growing concern about security over civil liberties.

Public perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS have remained consistently negative, but there's been a growing belief in its eventual success [1, 7].

Views on how well the military campaign against ISIS is going have changed little of the past year [7].
![image1](image1)
In December 2015, 35% of people believed the campaign was going very or fairly well, a slight increase from 30% in July 2015, but similar to the 36% and 34% in February 2015 and October 2014, respectively [7, ]![image1](image1).

However, there's an increased optimism about the ultimate success of the campaign. Two-thirds (66%) of the public now believe the U.S. and its allies will succeed, an 11-point increase from July (55%) [9].
![image6](image6)

There are significant partisan divides in the current assessment of the campaign [2]. Democrats are more likely to say the campaign is going at least fairly well (45%) compared to independents (33%) and Republicans (26%) [2].
![image4](image4)
In December 2015, 93% of Republicans,79% of Democrats and 79% of Independents view ISIS as a threat.
However, majorities across party linesRepublicans (65%), Democrats (72%), and independents (62%)believe the campaign will ultimately succeed [2].

A majority of Republicans (75%) are more concerned that the U.S. will not go far enough in stopping the militants [6].
![image2](image2)
In contrast, liberal Democrats (67%) express more concern that the U.S. will become too involved [10].

In summary, while the public consistently gives negative ratings to how the campaign is going, there's increasing optimism about its ultimate success, with notable differences in concerns across political affiliations.

Americans, across the political spectrum, have become more negative in their assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism [5]. However, views on whether Islam encourages violence are deeply divided along partisan lines [7, 12].

A significant majority of Republicans (68%) believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions, a figure that has remained relatively stable since 2014 [8, 12]. This is further supported by data that shows the percentages of Republicans saying Islamic religion is more likely than others to encourage violence among its believers is trending up.
![Republican, Independent and Democrats view on Islam](image2)

In contrast, only 30% of Democrats believe Islam is more likely to encourage violence, a decrease of 12 percentage points since 2014 [8, 12].
![Trend of if Islam encourages violence](image3)

Independents fall in between, with 45% saying Islam encourages violence [2].

These partisan differences are also reflected in opinions about whether Muslims in the U.S. should be subject to additional scrutiny. A majority of conservative Republicans (57%) support greater scrutiny of Muslims, while majorities of moderate/liberal Republicans (59%), independents (62%), conservative/moderate Democrats (67%), and liberal Democrats (87%) oppose it [4].
![How each political group think about scrutiny of Muslims](image4)

In addition, the public is divided on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence, and positive ratings for the government's handling of terrorism have decreased across all political groups [5, 6].

In conclusion, perceptions of Islam's encouragement of violence vary significantly among political affiliations, with Republicans more likely to view Islam as encouraging violence and Democrats less likely, while perceptions of government handling of terrorism have become more negative across the board.

Americans are divided about whether they see Islam as more likely than other religions to encourage violence among its believers [6]. Perceptions of whether Islam encourages violence have varied over time and significantly differ among political affiliations [7, 9].

From 2002 to 2015, the percentage of Republicans who believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions has generally increased, reaching a high of 68% in 2015. In contrast, the percentage of Democrats holding this view has decreased, particularly since 2014, dropping to 30% [7, 9]. Independents have remained relatively split on the issue, with 45% saying Islam is more likely to encourage violence and 45% saying it is not [2].
![Trend of opinions on Islam and violence by political affiliation](image1)

A broader view of the public opinion shows a decrease in those saying Islam encourages violence from 50% in 2014 to 46% in 2015.
![Changes in public opinion about Islam and violence over different periods](image3)

The shift in public opinion regarding how well the government has been doing in reducing the terrorist threat.
![Public opinion on government's handling of the terrorist threat](image6)

Despite these changing perceptions, the Republican Party has maintained a sizable advantage over the Democrats on the issue of terrorism [8].
![Public confidence in party capabilities for handling various issues, including terrorism](image5)
The public continues to perceive the Republican Party as better able to handle the terrorist threat at home, with 46% favoring Republicans and 34% favoring Democrats [8].

In summary, perceptions of Islam encouraging violence have become increasingly polarized along political lines, with a growing percentage of Republicans believing it does and a decreasing percentage of Democrats sharing this view, while public opinion favors the Republican Party's capability in handling terrorism.

There are significant differences in how various political and demographic groups perceive the scrutiny of Muslims in the United States.

Age plays a significant role. A large majority (80%) of young adults aged 18-29 believe that Muslims should not face additional scrutiny [10]. Those aged 30-49 also largely share this view (63% vs. 30%) [10]. However, views are more divided among those 50 and older, with half supporting greater scrutiny and 41% opposing it [11].
![Age and Scrutiny of Muslims](image1)

Race is another factor. Non-whites are more likely than whites to reject the idea of increased scrutiny of Muslims based on their religion [4]. Specifically, 74% of Black respondents and 66% of Hispanic respondents oppose greater scrutiny, compared to 57% of White respondents [4].

Educational attainment also correlates with these views. Nearly 70% of postgraduates and 65% of college graduates believe Muslims should not be subject to greater scrutiny [7].

Political affiliation shows a strong divide. Republicans are roughly evenly split, with 49% supporting greater scrutiny and 44% opposing it [9]. In contrast, clear majorities of independents (62%) and Democrats (76%) say U.S. Muslims should not be subject to greater scrutiny [9].
![Political Affiliation](image5)

Conservative Republicans stand out, with a majority (57%) supporting greater scrutiny of Muslims [12].

There's a connection between these perceptions and the perceived importance of terrorism. Republicans are much more likely to mention terrorism, defense issues, and national security as the most important problems facing the nation (41%) compared to independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) [6].
![Problems Facing Nation](image4)

In summary, perceptions of whether Muslims should face increased scrutiny vary significantly across demographic and political lines, with younger, non-white, more educated, and left-leaning individuals less likely to support such scrutiny, while older, white, less educated, and right-leaning, are more inclined to support such scrutiny which corelates with a heightened concern about terrorism.

Americans' ratings of the government's efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism have significantly declined and are currently at their lowest point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [4]. For the first time, a majority (52%) believe the government is doing "not too well" or "not at all well" in reducing the threat, compared to 46% who rate its performance as "very" or "fairly" well [4]. This marks a substantial 26-point decrease in positive ratings since January [4].

There's a growing concern among Americans that the government's anti-terror policies have not gone far enough to protect the country (56%), rather than going too far in restricting civil liberties (28%) [8].
![Trend in perceptions of government's anti-terrorism efforts](image7)

This perception varies significantly across demographic and political lines.
*   **Age:** Older Americans (50+) are more likely to give negative ratings (57%) than younger adults aged 18-29 (46%) [11].
*   **Education:** Individuals with postgraduate degrees are more positive (58%) than those with a bachelor's degree (48%) or less education (44%) [3].
     ![Government job reducing terrorist threat, by demographic group](image3)
*    **Political Affiliation:** There's a wide partisan divide. Republicans are far less likely (27%) than Democrats (64%) and independents (44%) to say the government is doing well [12].

Since early 2015, across all political groups, there is a down trend about government efforts to combat terrorism.
