Hispanics with a positive view of their current finances are more likely to believe their family's finances will improve [4].
![{conclusion}](image8)
This optimism is reflected in the expectation that their children will be better off financially [5]. The image shows that those in excellent or good financial condition have higher expectations for improvement.

Educational attainment also plays a role [10].
![{conclusion}](image3)
While those with some college experience or less than a high school education have similar levels of optimism (69% and 71% respectively), high school graduates are the most optimistic, with 79% expecting their children to be better off financially [10]. The breakdown by education levels can also seen in the image.

In conclusion, Hispanics who currently have better financial situation and those with high school education are more optimistic about their childrens financial future.

Latinos have become considerably more optimistic about their financial future since the Great Recession [1]. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve in the coming year increased by 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 and 2011 to 81% in 2015 [4].
![Hispanic and general public finances, 2004-2015](image4)
However, community economic indicators show a mixed picture [6]. The unemployment rate for Hispanics has improved since the Great Recession, but it remains above its 2006 low [7].
![Quarterly unemployment rate for Hispanics versus non-Hispanics from 2000 to 2015.](image7)
In 2014, the median household income for Hispanics was $42,491, a level essentially unchanged since the Great Recession [5].
![Hispanic Household Income Trends](image2)

In summary, while Latino perceptions of financial well-being have improved significantly, with increased optimism about their financial future, unemployment trends show a mixed economic picture, with the unemployment rate improving but still above pre-recession levels.

The data reveals a complex interplay of economic perceptions, unemployment trends, and wealth disparities between Hispanic and non-Hispanic populations.

Hispanic unemployment rates have improved since the Great Recession, falling from a high of 12.8% in the first quarter of 2010 to 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015 [8]. However, the rate remains above its 2006 low of 5% and is higher than that for non-Hispanic workers [8].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image8)
Despite the mixed economic picture, Hispanics remain more upbeat about national economic conditions than other groups [5]. A higher share of Hispanics rated economic conditions as good or excellent compared to whites (35% vs 25%) [5].
![% of adults who rate their personal finances as "excellent" or "good"](image4)
Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004, in contrast to the general public's view, which is lower [6].

However, median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, with the median household income for Hispanics at $42,491 in 2014, a level essentially unchanged since the recession [2].
![Median household income, poverty rate and median household wealth, 2000-2014](image2)
Hispanic households had the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009, and their net worth continued to fall after the recession, unlike white households [2].
![Median household income, poverty rate and median household wealth, 2000-2014](image2)

In conclusion, while Hispanics have a more positive outlook on the economy and their personal finances compared to non-Hispanics, their unemployment rates remain higher, their income has stagnated, and their wealth has declined, indicating persistent economic disparities.

Hispanic households have faced distinct economic challenges compared to all U.S. households from 2000 to 2015, particularly in terms of unemployment, income, poverty, and wealth.

**Unemployment:** The Hispanic unemployment rate has generally been higher than that of non-Hispanic workers. While the Hispanic unemployment rate has improved since the Great Recession, it remains above its 2006 low [7].
![Quarterly unemployment rate Hispanic vs. non-Hispanic](image4)

**Income:** The median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining at $42,491 in 2014, a level essentially unchanged [8].
![Median household income, poverty rate and median household wealth 2000-2014](image5)

**Poverty Rate:** The Hispanic poverty rate in 2014 was 23.6%, lower than the peak of 26.5% in 2010 but still above pre-recession levels [8].
![Median household income, poverty rate and median household wealth 2000-2014](image5)

**Wealth:** Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in their net worth through 2009, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [8].
![Median household income, poverty rate and median household wealth 2000-2014](image5)

In summary, while the Hispanic unemployment rate saw improvement after the recession, it remained higher than pre-recession levels and higher than that of non-Hispanics; their income stagnated, their poverty rate remained high, and their wealth declined significantly during and after the recession.

From 2008 to 2015, perceptions of personal financial situations among Latino groups significantly improved. Four-in-ten Latinos reported their personal finances were in "excellent" or "good" shape, a 17 percentage point increase since 2008 [10]. This improvement was observed across most major Latino demographic subgroups [8, 9]. For instance, positive views increased by 17 percentage points among U.S.-born Hispanics and 18 points among foreign-born Hispanics [6]. Similar gains were seen among Latino men (+16 points) and women (+18 points), and across different education levels [6].

![image6](image6)

However, perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living were different. Between 2014 and 2015, Hispanic views on this matter remained unchanged, with about half of all Hispanic adults reporting they were falling behind financially [4].

![image1](image1)

In 2015, about 53% of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living [11]. This sentiment was similar among blacks and whites in the same year [11].

In summary, while perceptions of personal financial situations among Latinos improved significantly between 2008 and 2015, about half still felt their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living in 2015.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from that of all adults, with noticeable trends in their daily internet habits.

Seniors are less likely to go online compared to the general population [7]. Only 59% of seniors (aged 65+) go online, and 47% have broadband at home, compared to 86% and 70% for all adults, respectively. ![A bar graph comparing cell phone, internet, and broadband usage between all adults and those aged 65 and over.](image2)

Smartphone and tablet ownership is also lower among seniors. While 55% of all adults own a smartphone, only 18% of seniors do. Similarly, tablet or e-reader ownership is at 43% for all adults but only 27% for seniors. ![A bar graph showing the percentage of smartphone and tablet ownership among all adults and those aged 65 and over.](image6)

However, seniors who do use the internet tend to be regular users [1, 7]. Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [1, 7].
![A bar chart showing the percentage of internet users in each age group who go online daily or almost daily, and 3-5 times per week.](image4)

In conclusion, internet usage and device ownership are lower among seniors compared to the general adult population, but seniors who are online tend to use the internet frequently.

Older adults' device ownership significantly impacts their internet usage patterns. While a majority of older adults (77%) own a cell phone, these are often basic models rather than smartphones [7]. Smartphone ownership among older adults is only 18% [7].

![Device ownership comparison between older adults and the general adult population.](image1)

Internet usage among older adults is at 59%, a figure that has been steadily increasing over the years but still lags behind the general population's 86% [6]. Broadband adoption at home is even lower, at 47% for those aged 65 and older.

![Internet and broadband usage among older adults by age, education, and income.](image2)

However, among those older adults who do use the internet, a large majority (71%) go online every day or almost every day [5]. An additional 11% go online three to five times per week [5].

![Internet usage frequency across different age groups.](image3)

This indicates that once older adults adopt the internet, they tend to use it frequently. Device ownership, especially smartphones and tablets, facilitates this regular usage. Although smartphone usage is low, tablets and e-readers are as popular as smartphones among the elderly [4].

![Smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership comparison between older adults and the general adult population.](image6)

In conclusion, although device ownership, particularly of smartphones, is lower among older adults compared to the general population, those who do own devices and use the internet tend to do so frequently.

Device ownership and online behaviors differ significantly between seniors (adults aged 65+) and the general adult population.

In terms of device ownership, smartphones are much more common among the general adult population than tablets or e-readers. [1] A significantly larger percentage of all adults own a smartphone (55%) compared to seniors (18%). ![Smartphone and Tablet or e-reader Ownership Among All Adults vs. Seniors](image1) However, among older adults, tablets and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones, with 18% owning each. [1] In fact, a larger proportion of seniors (27%) own either a tablet or an e-book reader, or both, compared to those who own a smartphone. [1], [7].

When it comes to cell phone ownership, a majority of older adults (77%) have a cell phone, but these are typically basic devices rather than smartphones. [5]
![Cell Phone, Internet, and Broadband Adoption: Seniors vs. All Adults](image3)

Regarding general internet usage, adoption rates among seniors trail the general population. While 86% of all U.S. adults go online, 59% of seniors report using the internet [11].
![Internet Adoption Over Time: Seniors vs. All Adults](image4)
Broadband adoption also shows a difference, Broadband adoption rates are at 47% for senior, while general adults are at 70%[image3].
![Breakdown of Seniors' Online Activity and SNS Usage](image2)
Moreover, a pie chart shows that 41% of older adults do not go online at all[image2].

Internet and broadband adoption among seniors are lower compared to the general public. However certain segments of the senior population, show rates equal to, or greater than, the general public [8], for instance:

*   **Age:** Younger seniors (65-69) are much more likely to go online (74%) and have broadband at home (65%) compared to those 80+ (37% online, 21% broadband) [image6].
*   **Education:** 87% of college graduate seniors use the Internet. Internet usage drops to 40% of seniors has high school grad or less. [image6]
* **Income**: Seniors with higher household incomes also use the Internet more. Internet adoption is at 90% for those earning $75,000+, compared to just 39% for those earning less than $30,000 [image6].

The data indicates a significant digital divide between seniors and the general adult population, although internet adoption among seniors is increasing over time.

Device ownership and online social networking habits among seniors (adults aged 65+) show distinct trends. While a significant portion of seniors are online, a smaller percentage use social networking sites.

A majority of seniors, 59%, report using the internet [8]. Internet usage among seniors has steadily increased over the years.
![Internet usage among seniors has steadily increased over the year](image2)
However, usage rates among seniors still trail the population as a whole by a substantial margin [8].

A quarter of seniors use online social networks [9]. Specifically, 27% of the total older adult population uses social networking sites like Facebook [1, 4].
![27% of older adults use social networking sites.](image4)
Seniors are more likely to own a tablet or e-book reader than a smartphone [6]. In fact, 18% of seniors own a smartphone, while 27% own either a tablet, an e-book reader, or both [7].
![Seniors are more likely to own tablets or e-book readers than smartphones.](image3)

In conclusion, a majority of seniors go online, but a much smaller percentage of them use social networking sites.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, and generally trail behind the rates of the general adult population [1].

Age is a major factor, with usage dropping off significantly around age 75 [3, 5].
![Internet and broadband adoption by age group.](image6)
For instance, 74% of seniors aged 65-69 go online, compared to only 37% of those aged 80 and older [2]. A similar trend is observed with broadband adoption, with 65% of 65-69 year-olds having broadband at home, versus just 21% of those 80 and older [2].

Education level also plays a crucial role.
![Internet and broadband adoption by education level.](image6)
Seniors with higher educational attainment have much higher adoption rates [7, 8]. For example, 87% of college-educated seniors go online, compared to 40% of those with a high school education or less.

Income is another significant factor.
![Internet and broadband adoption by income level.](image6)
Affluent seniors are much more likely to be online and have broadband [7, 8]. While 90% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more go online, only 39% of those earning less than $30,000 do [2].

These trends of cell phone and smartphone by age, education and income are also similar.
![Cell phone and smartphone adoption by age group, education level, and income level.](image3)

However, it's also indicated that.
![Internet use over time, comparing all adults to seniors aged 65+.](image5)
the internet use of older adults still trails the population as a whole by a substantial margin [1].

In summary, internet and broadband adoption among seniors is highest among those who are younger, more affluent, and well-educated, but these rates are still lower than those for the general adult population.

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption among seniors (adults aged 65+) varies significantly based on income and education.

For internet adoption:
*   Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 90% go online. [8]
*    Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, 39% go online. [8]
*   87% of seniors with a college degree go online. [6, 8]
*  Among seniors who have not attended college, 40% go online. [8]
*   ![Internet and broadband adoption by income and education](image3)

For broadband adoption:
*   Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, 82% have broadband at home. [8]
*    Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, 25% have broadband at home. [8]
*   76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters. [6, 8]
*    Among seniors who have not attended college, 27% have broadband at home. [8]

For cell phone adoption:
*	Cell phone ownership is common among all senior demographics, with majorities in every category owning one. [12]
*	Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000+, cell phone adoption rate is up to 92%.
*	Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually have cell phone adoption rate is 67%.
*	87% of seniors with a college degree has cell phone.
*	Among seniors who have not attended college, 70% have cell phone.
*   ![Cellphone and smartphone adoption by income and education](image8)

For smartphone adoption:

*  Smartphone adoption remains relatively low among seniors compared to the general population. [3]
*	Among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000+, smartphone adoption rate is up to 42%.
*	Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually, smartphone adoption rate is 8%
*	35% of seniors with a college degree has smartphone.
*	Among seniors who have not attended college, 10% have smartphone.
*   Just 18% of all seniors are smartphone adopters. [3]
*  ![Smartphone and Tablet/e-reader ownership rates.](image4)

In summary, internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates are significantly higher among seniors with higher income and education levels.

Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults (65+) show significant variation based on income and education levels, and generally, these rates are lower than the national averages for all adults.

Higher income and education correlate with higher adoption rates:

*   **Income:** Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have significantly higher adoption rates for internet use and broadband compared to those with lower incomes [1]. Specifically, 90% of seniors in this income bracket go online, and 82% have broadband at home.
    ![Table showing internet and broadband adoption rates by age, education, and income](image1)
*   **Education:** College graduates in the senior population are much more likely to use the internet and have broadband connections than those with a high school education or less [1]. 87% of college-educated seniors go online, and 76% have broadband [1].

Smartphone ownership follows a similar pattern:

*   **Income and Smartphone:** Affluent seniors ($75,000+ annual income) have higher smartphone ownership (42%) compared to the overall senior average (18%), it's still much lower than the general population at a similar income level (76%) [9, 4].
     ![Income and Smartphone ownership](image4)
*    **Education and Smartphone:** College-educated seniors are more likely to own smartphones compared with senior having high school grad or less [4].

*   **General Trend Comparison**: While 77% of seniors own cell phones, this is lower than the national average of 91% for all Americans [5]. Smartphone adoption is notably low among seniors (18%) compared to the national average (55%) [10].
![Smartphone adoption rates among seniors and adults](image5)

In conclusion, internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are strongly influenced by income and education levels, with higher income and education correlating with higher adoption, though these rates remain below the national averages.

Internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors varies significantly based on educational background.

Seniors with higher levels of education are much more likely to use the internet and own smartphones than those with lower levels of education [1], [2]. College graduates show the highest adoption rates, with 87% using the internet and 76% having broadband at home. ![Table showing internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors by education level.](image1) In contrast, seniors with a high school education or less have much lower rates: only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband at home [1].

Smartphone ownership follows a similar trend. Among seniors, 35% of college graduates own a smartphone.
![Table showing cell phone and smartphone adoption rates among seniors by education level.](image8)
This drops to 19% for those with some college education and further to 10% for those with a high school diploma or less [11].

In summary, internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors are strongly correlated with educational attainment, with higher education levels corresponding to significantly higher adoption rates.

Internet and broadband adoption, along with cell phone and smartphone ownership, varies significantly among seniors based on education and income levels.

**Income:**

*   **High Income:**  Seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more show high rates of internet and broadband adoption. Specifically, 90% go online, and 82% have broadband at home [12]. Cell phone ownership is also nearly universal in this group, While smartphone ownership is higher than the average for seniors, it still lags behind the general population of similar income [9, 6].
*   **Low Income:** Seniors earning less than $30,000 annually have much lower rates: 39% go online, and only 25% have broadband at home [12].

![image2](image2)

**Education:**

*   **College Graduates:**  A large majority (87%) of seniors with a college degree use the internet, and 76% have broadband [12, 2]. Cell phone ownership is high, and smartphone ownership is also relatively higher in this group [6].
*    **No College Education:** Among seniors who have not attended college, only 40% go online, and 27% have broadband at home [12].
![image5](image5)

**Overall Trends:**
Smartphone ownership is generally low among seniors across all demographics but decreases significantly for those in their mid-70s and becomes almost non-existent among those 80 and older [10].
Traditional cell phone ownership, on the other hand is has become significantly more common among all seniors and applys to every major demographic [11].

In Summary, internet and broadband adoption, as well as cell phone and smartphone ownership, are significantly higher among seniors with higher education and income levels, mirroring trends observed in the general population, although smartphone adoption rates are much lower across all senior demographics.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors varies significantly based on educational attainment and household income.

Seniors with higher education levels show much greater broadband adoption rates. For instance, 76% of seniors with a college degree have broadband at home, compared to only 27% of those who have not attended college [9].
![image5](image5)
Income also plays a crucial role. 82% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have broadband at home, whereas this figure drops to just 25% for seniors earning less than $30,000 annually [9].
![image6](image6)

In summary, broadband adoption among seniors is much higher for those with a college education and those with higher household incomes.

Education level significantly influences the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors [12]. Seniors with higher educational attainment are much more likely to own these devices. For instance, college graduates are about three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to seniors who have not attended college [12].
![e-book reader and tablet computer adoption rate by education level for 65+](image8)
This trend is consistent with the general population, where these devices are most popular among college graduates and higher-income Americans [12].
![A graph showing how internet use has changed across different age groups from 2006 to 2013.](image1)
Moreover, technology adoption, in general, varies significantly across different age groups over time. The graph illustrates that younger age groups (18-29) have consistently higher rates of internet usage compared to older groups, including seniors (65+) [7]. However, internet usage among seniors has been steadily increasing over the years [9].

In summary, education level is a major factor influencing the adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, mirroring trends seen in the general population, while technology adoption across all age groups shows that younger people are generally more likely to adopt new technologies, though usage among seniors has risen over time.

Workers' perceptions of workforce technologies are significantly influenced by their educational attainment. Those with higher education levels generally view technology more positively [10, 1]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and provided opportunities for career advancement, compared to those with high school diplomas or less [2, 7].

Here's a breakdown of the key differences:

*   **Positive Impact**: College graduates have a more positive view of various workplace technologies, including office productivity tools, smartphones, email/social media, and scheduling software [12].
*   **Career Advancement**: 53% of college graduates believe technology increased their career opportunities, compared to 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [2].
     ![image5](image5)
*   **Job Interest**: 64% of college graduates find their work more interesting due to technology, versus 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [2].
     ![image7](image7)
*   **Office Productivity Tools**: There's a 45-percentage point difference between college graduates (90%) and those with a high school diploma or less (45%) who feel these tools have had a positive impact [12].
     ![image3](image3)
*   Many people,($94\%$), are aware about driverless vehicle technology. [8]
*    **Future Expectations**: A significant majority (65%) of the public anticipates that most vehicles will be driverless within the next 50 years,with 9% thinking this shift occur in under 10 years. [8].
     ![image1](image1)

Workers with high educational attainment tend to have more positive opinions regarding workforce technology, and many Americans expect to see a lot more driverless cars on the road in the next few decades.

Workers with different educational backgrounds have varying opinions on how workplace technology affects their careers [8]. College graduates tend to have a more positive outlook compared to those with a high school diploma or less [9].

Heres a breakdown of how technology impacts careers based on education:

*   **Office Productivity Tools:** A significant difference is seen with office tools like word processing and spreadsheet software. 90% of college graduates see a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less [9].
*    **General Career Impact**:
![Impact of technology on workers' careers based on education levels.](image1)
*   **Specific Technologies:** The positive views extend to other technologies like email/social media (27-point difference), smartphones (22 points), and scheduling software (21 points) [9].
*   **Overall Positive Impact**: Only 2% of college graduates feel that none of the six technologies measured had a positive impact, in contrast to 24% of workers with high school diplomas or less [9].
*   **Detailed View of Technologies:**
![Positive and negative impacts of different technologies.](image5)

In addition to views on current workplace technologies, many Americans are also thinking about future technologies, such as driverless vehicles [1]. The widespread expectation is that these technologies will significantly change transportation.

*   **Awareness and Predictions:** 94% of Americans are aware of driverless vehicle development, and around two-thirds believe most vehicles will be driverless within 50 years [1].
*   **Timeline Expectations:**
![Expected timeline for the widespread adoption of driverless vehicles.](image4)

In summary, college graduates generally view workplace technologies more positively than those with a high school diploma or less, and there's a broad expectation that driverless cars will become common within the next 50 years.

Americans have high expectations for the future of automation, particularly regarding driverless vehicles, with a significant majority aware of their development and many anticipating widespread adoption [1]. Roughly two-thirds of the public anticipates that most vehicles on the road will be driverless within the next half-century, with 9% predicting that this will occur in the next 10 years [1].
![A bar graph showing the timeline of expectations for most cars being driverless.](image8)

In contrast, current experiences with workplace technologies are more mixed [4]. While many workers report positive impacts from technologies like word processing software, smartphones, and email, a substantial portion views them as neutral or even detrimental to their careers [8].
![A bar graph showing workers' views on how technology has affected their jobs.](image4)
Workers express a diversity of views when asked about various technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), email or social media (60%), software for schedules (54%), customer self-service technologies (48%) and industrial robots (27%) [8].

Moreover, the perceived benefits of these technologies often correlate with educational attainment, with more highly educated workers more likely to view them positively [6].

In summary, while Americans are largely optimistic about the future widespread adoption of driverless vehicles, their experiences with current workforce technologies are mixed, with benefits not uniformly distributed across all workers.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have a more positive outlook on workplace technologies compared to those with lower educational attainment [3, 10]. This difference in perception is significant when it comes to how technology impacts job interest and career opportunities.

College graduates are much more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting. ![A graph showing 64% college grad+ say technology made their work more interesting](image1)
In contrast, a smaller percentage of workers with only a high school diploma or less find that technology has made their jobs more interesting [2, 8].

A similar trend is evident in perceptions about career advancement.
![A graph showing 53% college grad+ say technology increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)
College graduates are more inclined to believe that technology has increased their career opportunities, whereas those with a high school education or less are less likely to hold this view [2, 8].

The survey covered six common workplace technologies, revealing that college-educated workers are substantially more likely to view each of these technologies as having a positive impact on their careers [11].
Specifically, there's a 45-percentage-point difference between college graduates (90%) and those with a high school diploma or less (45%) who feel that office productivity tools have had a positive professional impact [1].
![A graph showing 90% college grad+ say technology had a positive impact, for word processing or spreadsheet software](image4)
Substantial differences also exist for other technologies, like email, social media, and smartphones [1].

In summary, perceptions of workplace technologies vary significantly by education level, with college graduates more likely to report positive impacts on job interest and career opportunities compared to those with a high school education or less.

Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to report that technology has positively impacted their work by making it more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement [2, 7].

Workers with at least a four-year college degree have more positive views of workplace technologies compared to those with high school diplomas or less [11]. The survey measured six specific technologies, office productivity tools such as word processing or spreadsheet software have the most pronounced differences: 90% of college graduates and 45% of high school graduates or less believe that office productivity technologies have had a positive impact on them professionally [11]. However, several other technologies show significant differences between the two groups, for example, email or social media (27 points), smartphones (22 points), and software that manages workers' daily schedules and routines (21 points) [11].
![image1](image1)
College graduates are more likely to state that technology made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) compared with workers with high school diplomas or less [12]. In addition, 24% of workers with high school diplomas or less say that none of the six technologies has positively impacted their jobs or careers; for college graduates, that figure is just 2% [6, 11].

In conclusion, educational attainment significantly influences the perceived impact of technologies on work, with higher education levels correlating with more positive views on making work more interesting and increasing advancement opportunities.

Workers with higher levels of education tend to view technology's impact on their careers more positively than those with lower educational levels [4, 8, 9, 11].

Specifically, college graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement [10]. For instance, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of workers with high school diplomas or less [10]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates say technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, while only 32% of those with high school diplomas or less agree [10].

![Technology has varied impacts on job interest and opportunities based on education.](image1)

In contrast, workers with high school diplomas or less are more likely to express negative or neutral views about technology's impact [5, 11]. A significant portion of this group indicates that technologies have not impacted their careers meaningfully [2]. In fact, 24% of workers with high school diplomas or less say that *none* of the six technologies measured (including word processing, spreadsheets, email, social media, smartphones, and scheduling software) have positively impacted their jobs, compared to just 2% of college graduates [1]. The difference between these groups is especially pronounced for office productivity tools where there's a 45-percentage point difference in positive impact (90% for college grads vs. 45% for high school grads or less) [1].

![Different technologies have affected the jobs of employees with varying levels of education.](image7)

In summary, educational attainment significantly influences perceptions of technology in the workplace, with higher education correlating with more positive views on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans' awareness of automation influences their views on machines taking over human jobs. Those who have heard a lot about this concept are more likely to find it realistic. [6, 10].

Specifically, 48% of those who have heard a lot about the concept find it extremely realistic, compared to 14% who have heard a little and 4% who have heard nothing. Enthusiasm also increases with awareness: 47% of those who have heard a lot are enthusiastic about the concept, compared to 30% of those who have heard a little and 18% of those who have heard nothing [10].
![Levels of awareness effect](image1)

However, even with greater enthusiasm, those with high awareness express just as much worry as those with lower awareness levels [11].
![Enthusiastic and Worried](image2)

A significant majority of Americans, regardless of their awareness levels, express worry about a future where machines perform many jobs currently done by humans [5]. The percentages of those worried are: 76% of individuals who heard a lot, 72% who heard a little and 69% who heard nothing [5].
![Worry levels about concept of automation](image1)

Regarding expected outcomes, most Americans anticipate more negative than positive consequences from widespread automation. [7]. A large majority (76%) expect increased economic inequality. [4].
![Possible Outcomes](image6)
Only 25% believe the economy will create many new, better-paying jobs for humans.[12].

In summary, higher awareness of automation leads to greater perceived realism and enthusiasm, but it does not reduce worry, and most Americans expect negative outcomes such as increased inequality from this technological shift.

Americans generally view the scenario of machines performing many human jobs as plausible, expressing more concern than enthusiasm and expecting mostly negative outcomes [10].

There are notable differences in opinion between Democrats and Republicans regarding policies on workforce automation. Democrats and those leaning Democratic are significantly more supportive of a universal basic income and a national service program if machines were to replace a large number of human jobs [12]. Specifically, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income compared to 38% of Republicans, and 66% of Democrats favor a national service program compared to 46% of Republicans [12].
These partisan differences are visually represented in the following chart:

![Support for policies by political party](image6)

However, there is strong bipartisan support for the idea of limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs [12].

The support levels across all demographics are high for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs. A significant majority, 85%, of Americans favor this policy, with 47% strongly favoring it [3]. This support is consistent across party lines, with 85% of Democrats and 86% of Republicans in favor of this measure. Opposition to this idea is minimal, with only 3% strongly opposed [6]. This broad agreement is also illustrated here:

![Public views on limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image1)

In conclusion, while Democrats are more supportive of government interventions like universal basic income and national service programs in response to workforce automation, both Democrats and Republicans overwhelmingly support limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.

Americans' views on the government's responsibility for workers displaced by automation, and on limits to automation, are significantly shaped by their political affiliations and educational backgrounds.

Regarding government obligations, there's a sharp partisan divide. A majority of Democrats (65%) believe the government should care for displaced workers, even with higher taxes, while a similar majority of Republicans (68%) think individuals should be responsible for themselves [4].
![image8](image8)

However, views on limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate show a different pattern, with educational attainment playing a more prominent role than political affiliation. A larger proportion of individuals with a high school diploma or less (70%) support limits on job automation, compared to college graduates (41%) [6]. Politically, a slight majority of both Republicans (54%) and Democrats (60%) believe there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines[2].

In summary, political affiliation strongly influences opinions on the government's obligation to assist workers displaced by automation, while education levels significantly affect views on limiting the number of jobs businesses can automate.

Political affiliation significantly influences American views on policies concerning workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more likely to believe the government has an obligation to care for workers displaced by automation, even if it means higher taxes [3]. This is supported by data showing 65% of Democrats in favor, compared to only 30% of Republicans [3, ![The image shows the survey result about how different groups think about workforce automation and job displacement](image1)].

Furthermore, Democrats are substantially more supportive of a universal basic income (77% favor) and a national service program (66% favor) compared to Republicans (38% and 46% favor, respectively) [4, 9, ![The image shows the survey result of different political affiliations towards some policies](image6)].

However, there's more agreement between parties on limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines. A majority of both Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) support limits on job replacement by automation [4, 11, ![The image shows the survey result about how different groups think about workforce automation and job displacement](image1)].

In summary, Democrats are more supportive of government intervention and social safety nets in response to job displacement due to automation, while Republicans generally favor individual responsibility, though both parties show substantial support for limiting business automation.

Attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly among different age groups and educational levels.

Younger adults, particularly those aged 18-24, are more likely to report having been personally impacted by workforce automation, through job loss or reduced pay/hours [3].
![image4](image4)

Workers with higher levels of education tend to have more positive views of workplace technologies [4, 5]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement, compared to those with a high school diploma or less [2].
![image5](image5)

Workers with high school diplomas or less are much less likely to express positive attitudes towards current workforce technologies [10, 12]. A minority of Americans (6%) have already been impacted by automation in their own jobs and careers [3].
![image3](image3)

Workers in certain industries, such as hospitality, service, or retail, are more likely to view their jobs as being at risk of automation compared to those in other industries like education [6].
![image6](image6)

In summary, attitudes towards workforce automation and technology's impact vary significantly, with younger workers and those with less education reporting more negative experiences and perceptions, while those with higher education levels generally view technology more positively.

Workers' views on the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly based on their educational attainment and demographics.

College graduates and those with higher levels of education tend to view technology as a positive force that enhances their work and career prospects [1]. They are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement [9]. For instance, 64% of college graduates believe technology has made their work more interesting, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [9].
![image1](image1)
In contrast, workers who have not attended college, especially those with a high school diploma or less, are less likely to view workforce technologies positively [1]. Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less feel that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% believe it has increased their career advancement opportunities [10].
![image6](image6)
Moreover, many workers express mixed views about the impact of various workforce technologies [5, 7]. A substantial share indicates that technologies such as word processing software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have positively impacted their careers [8]. However, a significant portion also feels that these technologies have had a neutral or damaging effect [2].

The survey highlights the disparate impacts of workforce technologies, with benefits accruing mostly to workers with high levels of formal education [2]. This disparity is also seen in the broader impact of technology on careers, where college graduates are more likely to say technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities [12].

In conclusion, perceptions of the impact of workforce automation and technology vary significantly, with college-educated workers generally viewing technology more positively than those with less education.

Workers' perceptions of how technology impacts their jobs, in terms of interest and advancement opportunities, vary significantly based on their education levels and the specific technologies involved [1, 6, 8].

College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their career advancement opportunities [5, 6]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates, compared to 38% of those with a high school diploma or less, believe technology has made their work more engaging [5].

![image5](image5)

In terms of career advancement, 53% of college graduates versus 32% of workers with a high school diploma or less feel that technology has boosted their opportunities [5, 11].
![image4](image4)

A substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have had a positive impact on their own careers [10].
![image6](image6)

Workers with high school diplomas or less are much less likely to express positive attitudes towards current workforce technologies [12]. Only 38% find that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and 32% believe it has increased their career advancement opportunities [11].

In summary, higher education levels correlate with a more positive perception of technology's impact on job interest and advancement, with significant differences observed between college graduates and those with a high school diploma or less, across various specific technologies.

Social media evokes a range of emotions, with amusement being the most prevalent across all age groups [5]. However, the frequency of experiencing certain emotions varies significantly with age [7].

Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report feeling amused frequently (54%) compared to older adults aged 65 and over (30%) [6].
![image8](image8)
The image shows the percentage of social media users in each age group who say they frequently experience certain emotions.

While amusement is common, younger adults are also more prone to negative emotions like loneliness (15% of 18-29-year-olds) and depression [7, 8]. In contrast, older adults experience a more balanced mix of amusement (30%) and anger (24%) [7].
![image7](image7)

This chart indicates that 44% of all users frequently feel amused, while 25% frequently feel angry.

In summary, while amusement is the most common emotion experienced on social media across all age groups, younger users are more likely to feel amused but also experience negative emotions like loneliness more frequently than older users.

Social media users experience a range of emotions, with some variations across age groups. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report frequently feeling amused by content on social media. [4, 6].
![image5](image5)
In contrast, older adults (65+) experience amusement and anger with more comparable frequency [6]. Specifically, 30% of older users frequently feel amused, while 24% frequently feel angry [4]. Younger adults are also more likely to frequently encounter content that makes them feel lonely [6].

In terms of content, a majority of users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts [12].
![image1](image1)
Moreover, users often see a mix of kind/supportive and mean/bullying behaviors on these platforms [2].

In conclusion, different age groups experience emotions differently on social media, with younger adults more frequently feeling amused but also lonely, while older adults experience amusement and anger at similar levels, and all age groups are commonly exposed to dramatic or argumentative content.

Social media users experience a range of emotions, with amusement being the most common [6]. However, there are variations across age groups. Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to report feeling lonely (15%) compared to older adults (4% for those 50 and older) [7].
![image3](image3)
In terms of anger, identical shares across age groups frequently encounter content that evokes this emotion [7].
Content-wise, users often see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and people making accusations without all the facts [10].
![image5](image5)
A majority of social media users also report seeing a mix of kind/supportive behavior and mean/bullying behavior [4]. Men are more likely than women to report seeing mean or bullying behavior (29% vs. 19%) [12].
![image6](image6)

In conclusion, while amusement is the most common emotion experienced on social media, younger users report higher instances of loneliness, and men are more likely to observe mean or bullying behavior.

Social media experiences vary significantly across age groups and genders, influencing emotions and exposing users to various types of content.

Younger users, aged 18-29, report feeling amused more frequently (54%) than older age groups [4]. However, this age group also experiences higher rates of loneliness (15%) and depression (17%) compared to older demographics.
![image8](image8)

In contrast, older users (65+) report lower instances of these negative emotions [4]. The data indicates that 25% of all social media users frequently feel angry [2].
![image4](image4)

Regarding behaviors, a substantial portion of users report seeing a mix of positive and negative interactions. While 54% see an equal mix of kind/supportive and mean/bullying behaviors, men are more likely (29%) than women (19%) to report seeing predominantly mean or bullying behavior [3, 9].
![image7](image7)

The most common types of posts encountered include those that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58% see this frequently) and those where people make accusations or start arguments without having all the facts (59% see this frequently) [8].
![image3](image3)

In addition, 74% of social media users reported seeing content that does not make them angry.
![image1](image1)

In summary, different age groups and genders have diverse experiences on social media, with younger users reporting higher rates of both positive (amusement) and negative (loneliness, depression) emotions, while men are more likely to encounter mean or bullying behavior.

There are notable differences between men's and women's perceptions of online behaviors. Men are more likely than women to report seeing bullying and deceptive behavior on social media [2, 12].

Specifically, 29% of men versus 19% of women report seeing more bullying than kind behavior [2].
![image4](image4)
This aligns with the finding that men are about twice as likely as women (24% vs. 13%) to say they more often see people being deceptive [12]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to report seeing kind or supportive behavior, although the largest shares of both genders see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [2].

In terms of correcting misinformation, while the majority of both genders see an equal mix, men are more likely to perceive deceptive behavior [12].

![image2](image2)
Regarding the frequency of encountering dramatic or exaggerated posts, a majority of social media users (58%) frequently see this type of content [1, 5]. The data provided, it doesn't offer a gender breakdown for this specific perception.

In summary, men are more likely to perceive negative online behaviors like bullying and deception, while women are slightly more inclined to see positive or supportive interactions; however both genders equally and frequently see dramatic or exaggerated posts.

Men and women perceive social media content and behavior differently, influencing how platforms tailor their services.

Men are about twice as likely as women (24% vs. 13%) to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media [1].
![image4](image4)
Men are also more likely than women (29% vs. 19%) to report seeing mean or bullying behavior more often than kind behavior [3], [6]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) perceive an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation, and similar majorities (52% of men and 56% of women) see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [1], [3].

Social media platforms utilize vast quantities of user data, including behaviors, likes, and clicks, to deliver individually targeted content [7]. User comfort with this data usage is context-dependent [7], [12]. Majorities across age groups find it acceptable for sites to use their data to show them local events, but not for political campaign ads [2].
![image3](image3)

In conclusion, men tend to encounter more negative and deceptive behavior on social media, while women report a slightly more positive or balanced experience, social media platforms tailor recommendations and ads based on user data.

User comfort with social media platforms' use of personal data is highly dependent on the specific context and purpose for which the data is used [5, 9]. A significant majority (75%) of social media users are comfortable with their data being used to recommend local events [6, 12]. However, this comfort level drops significantly when data is used for political messaging, with only 37% finding it acceptable [6].

Age plays a crucial role in these perceptions. While majorities across age groups are comfortable with data being used for event recommendations, there are notable differences in other areas [8, 10]:

![Percentage of social media users comfortable with data usage for various purposes, categorized by age groups.](image3)

  *   **Recommending Connections:** Younger users (18-49) are more accepting (66%) of social media platforms using their data to recommend connections, compared to older users (65+) (36%) [1, 4].
  *   **Showing Advertisements:** Nearly 60% of users ages 18 to 49 think it is acceptable, while the quote does not metion the acceptance of old user [4].
  *   **Political Messaging:** Majorities across all age groups find it unacceptable for platforms to use their data for political campaign ads [8].
Another image that shows the detail percentage:
![Acceptability of social media data usage by age groups.](image2)

Overall, user comfort levels with social media platforms using their personal data vary significantly depending on the purpose, with a clear preference for non-intrusive, beneficial uses like event recommendations, and strong opposition to uses like political messaging, with some variation affected by age.

Americans express significant reservations about the fairness and, to a lesser extent, the effectiveness of automated decision-making systems across various applications.

The public is generally skeptical about the fairness of these programs, with no single system being viewed as fair by a clear majority [4]. The "personal finance score" and "video job interview analysis" are considered fair by particularly small percentages of the population (32% and 33%, respectively) [4]. A significant portion of the public believes that computer programs inherently reflect human bias [6]. Specifically, 58% believe that computer programs will always have some level of bias, though 40% think such programs *can* be designed to be bias-free [6].
![Perceptions of bias in computer programs, with 58% believing they always reflect bias and 40% believing they can be bias-free.](image4)

There's also a notable contrast in attitudes toward different systems performing similar tasks. For example, while similar proportions of the population believe the criminal risk score and personal finance score programs would be effective (49% and 54% respectively), a significantly larger share thinks the criminal risk score is fair (50% versus 32%) [8].
![Effectiveness vs Fairness of Automated Decision Making Systems](image8)
This discrepancy is further emphasized by the 22-percentage-point difference between those who believe the personal finance score program would be effective and those who believe it's fair [11].

Public concerns around these algorithms span various dimensions, such as potential privacy violations, inability to understand complex situations, and creating unfair situations for those evaluated. [6]

Major concerns frequently cited include:
*   **Unfairness**: Especially prevalent in responses to personal finance scores, job interviews, and automated job applicant screening [7].
*    **Removal of Human Element**: A key concern with automated resume screening and video job interview analysis [7].
*   **Inability to Capture Nuance**: Mentioned across several contexts, particularly concerning criminal risk scores [7].

![Acceptability of Automated Systems by Type](image2)
A majority of the public considers both the personal finance score algorithm (68%) and computer-aided video job analysis (67%) unacceptable [2].

In summary, public trust in automated decision-making systems is low due to concerns about fairness, potential biases, and the removal of human judgment, with significant variations depending on the specific application of the technology.

Public perception of President Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness is significantly lower compared to previous presidents, and this perception is sharply divided along political lines.

A majority of the public (58%) reports trusting Trump's statements less than those of previous presidents [3]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats.
![image4](image4)
Almost all Democrats and Democratic leaners (94%) say they trust what Trump says less than they trusted previous presidents [7].

Conversely, a majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (58%) say they trust what Trump says *more* than previous presidents [11]. Only 15% of Republicans say they trust his rhetoric less [11].
![image4](image4)

Regarding ethical standards, the contrast is equally stark.
![image1](image1)
The ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are viewed lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations [10]. Only 39% of the public rate the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, while 59% rate them as not good or poor [5]. A significant partisan divide exists, with 76% of Republicans rating the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, compared to 90% of Democrats rating them as not good or poor [1].

In conclusion, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower than those of previous presidents and are deeply polarized along partisan lines.

Public perceptions of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness are notably lower than those of previous presidents, with significant partisan divisions influencing these views.

A majority of the public (58%) trusts what Trump says less than what previous presidents said while in office [6]. This distrust is particularly pronounced among Democrats, with 94% expressing less trust in Trump's statements compared to previous presidents [8].
![Trust in Trump's statements compared to previous presidents, broken down by political affiliation.](image6)
In contrast, 58% of Republicans trust Trump's statements more than those of previous presidents [11].

Views of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are at record lows compared with previous administrations [4]. Partisan divisions are evident, with 76% of Republicans saying the ethical standards are excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats rate them as not good or poor [9].
![Public ratings of the ethical standards of top administration officials, categorized by political party.](image7)
There is also a consensus that Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns.
A majority (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to publicly release his tax returns, including 91% of Democrats and 32% of Republicans [10].

In summary, the public generally trusts Trump less and views his administration's ethical standards as lower compared to previous administrations, driven largely by partisan views.

Public perceptions of Trump's presidency vary significantly across political affiliations and differ from views of previous administrations in several key areas.

**Ethical Standards:**

Views of the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are notably low compared to previous administrations [1, 10]. A significant partisan divide exists, with 76% of Republicans rating the ethical standards of top officials as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats rate them as not good or poor [3].
![image2](image2)

**Economic Impact:**

There's a positive perception of Trump's impact on the economy, with 40% believing his policies have improved economic conditions [11]. However, partisan views on this matter have become increasingly polarized [12].
![image4](image4)

**Long-Term Success:**

Expectations for Trump's long-term success are low, with 47% predicting he will be an unsuccessful president [5]. Republicans are more optimistic, with 65% believing he will be successful [6]. In comparison, fewer people say it's "too early to tell" whether Trump will be successful than they did for his three most recent predecessors [5].
![image3](image3)

**Partisan Views and Comparison to Previous Presidents:**

Partisans are more likely to offer a view on Trumps success than prior presidents [7]. Republicans' views of Trump's long-term outlook are similar to their views of Bush in his third year [8]. Democrats are overwhelmingly negative about Trump's potential success, with 80% believing he will be unsuccessful [4].
![image8](image8)

In terms of how much the public trusts the information from White house
![image5](image5)

Overall, perceptions of Trump's presidency are deeply divided along party lines, with Republicans generally holding more positive views, particularly regarding the economy, while Democrats express negative views, especially concerning ethical standards and long-term success.

Public opinion on Trump's presidency is highly polarized along partisan lines, significantly more so than for his predecessors Obama, Bush, and Clinton.

A large majority of Democrats (80%) believe Trump will be an unsuccessful president [1], while a substantial portion of Republicans (65%) believe he will be successful.
![image2](image2)
This partisan divide is starker than in earlier presidencies.

Fewer people say it's "too early to tell" about Trump's success compared to previous presidents at similar points in their terms [3, 5]. This indicates that opinions about Trump have solidified more quickly.
![image3](image3)
In January 2019, 47% of the total respondents believed Trump would be unsuccessful, 29% believed he would be successful, and 23% said it was too early to tell [5].

Public perceptions of Trump's economic policies reflect growing polarization.
![image1](image1)
In January 2019, 79% of Republicans believed his economic policies had made things better, while 46% of Democrats believed they had made things worse [9].

Overall, the data reveal a highly polarized public opinion environment regarding Trump's presidency, with faster opinion formation and deeper partisan divides compared to his predecessors. Perceptions are starkly divided along party lines, with Republicans generally optimistic and Democrats overwhelmingly pessimistic.

Views on the Mueller investigation and Trump's handling of it are highly partisan [2].

A majority of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents (65%) believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run [12]. In contrast, a large share of Democrats and Democratic leaners (80%) think that Trump will be an unsuccessful president [9].
![image6](image6)

These partisan views are also reflected in the levels of confidence in Mueller's investigation. Among Republicans and Republican leaners, a larger share says they are not too or not at all confident in Mueller (58%) [10].
![image7](image7)
On the other hand, about seven-in-ten Democrats and Democratic leaners (72%) are at least somewhat confident in the fairness of Muellers investigation [10].
![image8](image8)

In direct answer to the question: Republicans generally believe Trump will be successful, while Democrats generally believe he will be unsuccessful, with corresponding levels of confidence in Mueller's investigation, where Republicans express less confidence and Democrats express more.

Americans' views on economic conditions and job availability show significant differences based on political affiliation, with notable trends over time.

There's a noticeable partisan gap in how people view job availability [6]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to believe there are plenty of jobs available locally (71% vs. 53%) [1, 6]. This aligns with the broader trend of Republicans having a more positive outlook on their personal financial situation [3].
![image4](image4)

This partisan divide has persisted over time, as illustrated by a graph showing the percentage of Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats who believe there are plenty of jobs available in their community from 2001 to 2019.
![image2](image2)

The trend of Republicans being more optimistic about job availability isn't new, but the gap has widened in recent years [9]. Both parties have seen an increase in positive views about local job opportunities, reaching levels not seen in the last two decades [4]. Overall, public views on local job availability are at their most positive in decades [8]. Six-in-ten adults believe there are plenty of jobs in their community, a record high since the question was first asked in 2001 [5]. However, there's a distinction made between "jobs" and "good jobs," with the latter seen as less widely available [10, 12].
![image7](image7)
Republicans have a more optimistic view of their personal finances over time compared with Democrats.
![image8](image8)

In summary, perceptions of economic conditions and job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding a more optimistic view, and these positive views have increased over time for both parties.

Americans' perceptions of job availability have significantly changed, with a majority believing there are plenty of jobs available in their communities [1]. This perception is clearly divided along partisan lines, with a greater percentage of Republicans believing in ample job availability compared to Democrats [4].

Specifically, 71% of Republicans report that there are plenty of jobs available, in contrast to 53% of Democrats [6].
![image1](image1)
This partisan gap in views of job availability has widened over time, especially since the election of President Trump. The perceptions of job availability have risen in both parties, especially the GOP [5].
![image2](image2)

Perceptions of the job market have become more positive in recent years.
![image6](image6)

In summary, perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans being more optimistic, and these perceptions have become increasingly positive and polarized over time.

Public opinion on Wall Street's impact on the U.S. economy is sharply divided along partisan lines [9]. A majority of Republicans and Republican leaners (55%) believe that Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts [2].
![A survey of U.S. adults conducted Jan. 9-14, 2019, showing that 55% of Republicans/Lean Republicans believe Wall Street helps the American economy more than it hurts.](image1)
In contrast, Democrats and Democratic leaners are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy more and 41% saying it helps more [7].

However, despite differing views on Wall Street's impact, there's a broad dissatisfaction with national conditions [3]. Public dissatisfaction has been high for over a decade, and it has increased in recent times [12].
![A graph showing the trend of satisfaction and dissatisfaction with the way things are going in the country from 1990 to 2019.](image5)
Currently, 70% of Americans are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country [5]. This dissatisfaction is seen across party lines, though it is particularly pronounced among Democrats [6, 8].
![A graph charting satisfaction levels among Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats from 1990 to 2019, highlighting a significant drop in satisfaction among Democrats during the Trump presidency.](image7)
Republican satisfaction, while higher than that of Democrats, has also seen a decline, reaching its lowest point since late 2017 [1].

In summary, Republicans generally view Wall Street positively, while Democrats are divided, and both parties express high dissatisfaction with national conditions, which has been a long-term trend.

Public satisfaction levels have significantly decreased from 1990 to 2019, accompanied by increasing political polarization.

From 1990 to 2019, overall public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation has risen. In the most recent data, 70% of Americans report being dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country, compared to just 26% who are satisfied [5]. This dissatisfaction has increased markedly since September, reflecting a 9 percentage point rise [11].
![Public dissatisfaction with the way things are going in the country, 1990-2019](image5)

Political affiliations have become more polarized over this period. Republican satisfaction has seen a notable drop, with the lowest GOP satisfaction rating since late 2017 [2]. Republican satisfaction dropped 12 percentage points from September to the time of the data collection [2]. In contrast, Democratic satisfaction has remained consistently low throughout Trump's presidency, with no more than 16% expressing satisfaction at any point [3].
![Satisfaction levels among Republicans and Democrats from 1990 to 2019.](image4)

These trends highlight a deepening partisan divide. More Republicans believe that Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts it (55% vs. 31%) [6]. Democrats are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy and 41% saying it helps [7].
![Views of Wall Street's impact on the economy by political affiliation.](image8)

Public satisfaction has decreased, and political views have become more polarized, especially regarding Wall Street's impact on the economy.

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts differs significantly between Republicans and Democrats. A large majority of Republicans express confidence in his ability to do, while Democrats overwhelmingly lack confidence.

More specifically, among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, 88% indicate they are very or somewhat confident in Trump to Make good appointments to the federal courts. In stark contrast, only 12% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents share the same level of confidence.
![image7](image7)

This partisan divide in confidence levels for appointing federal judges is similar to the pattern seen for other tasks. For instance, regarding negotiating favorable trade agreements, 89% of Republicans are confident in Trump's ability, compared to just 19% of Democrats [6]. Similarly, for managing the executive branch effectively, 83% of Republicans express confidence, a stark contrast to the mere 8% of Democrats who feel the same ![image7](image7). The confidence level is high among Republicans and significantly lower among Democrats.

In summary, there's a wide partisan gap in confidence regarding Trump's ability to appoint federal judges, mirroring similar divides on other presidential responsibilities like trade negotiations and executive management.

Americans are divided on their confidence in Trump's ability to keep his business interests separate from his presidential decisions, with significant differences based on political affiliation.

Overall, only about three-in-ten Americans (28%) are very confident that Trump keeps his own business interests separate from the decisions he makes as president, and another 13% say they are somewhat confident [8].
![{Overall, Republican/Lean Republican, and Democrat/Lean Democrat views on whether Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns from 2017-2019}](image1)
A majority of Republicans express confidence in this area, with 55% saying they are very confident and 23% somewhat confident [5]. Conservative Republicans (66%) are much more likely to express strong confidence than moderate and liberal Republicans (39%) [5].
![{Confidence levels in Trump separating business interests and presidential decisions, broken down by political affiliation and level of confidence}](image8)
In stark contrast, Democrats are overwhelmingly skeptical.  Nearly seven-in-ten (69%) say they are not at all confident, and another 20% are not too confident [6]. This skepticism is even more pronounced among liberal Democrats, with 83% expressing no confidence at all [6].

Regarding the release of tax returns, the partisan divide persists. A majority of the public (64%) believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [9]. However, most Republicans (64%) continue to say that Trump does not have this responsibility, while only 32% believe he does [10].

In conclusion, confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business and presidential roles is highly polarized along party lines, with Republicans largely confident and Democrats overwhelmingly skeptical, mirroring the divide over whether he should release his tax returns.

Partisan divides significantly affect perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions. Democrats and Republicans hold divergent opinions on nearly all aspects of the pandemic [8].

Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that the federal government response was inadequate (82% vs. 21%) and that COVID-19 restrictions were lifted too quickly (82% vs. 31%) [2].
![Partisan differences in reasons why the coronavirus outbreak has continued](image8)

Democrats also give higher positive ratings to state and local government officials than Republicans do [5]. There are wide partisan differences in the views of public health officials. [9].
![Ratings of various officials and organizations, broken down by political party.](image1)
This shift has come almost entirely among Republicans,with positive views for CDC officials dropping from 84% to 53% from March to August, while Democratic views stayed steady, going from 74% down to 72% [12].

Republicans are less likely to believe new infections are the primary cause of increasing confirmed cases, while Democrats view new infections as the cause [11].
![The graph depicts diverging views between Republicans and Democrats on the causes of rising coronavirus cases.](image2)

Overall, Democrats overwhelmingly view the U.S. response as less effective compared to other wealthy countries (87%), while only 22% of Republicans say the U.S. response has been more effective [8].
![Data on how Republicans and Democrats rate the U.S.'s response to the coronavirus in comparison to other wealthy nations.](image7)

In conclusion, partisan divides deeply affect perceptions of the U.S. COVID-19 response, with Democrats generally more critical of the response and more trusting of public health officials, while Republicans show declining trust in these institutions and are less likely to attribute rising cases to new infections.

Partisan differences significantly impact the perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak.

The ratings for public health officials, such as those with the CDC, show a wide partisan gap [7]. Positive assessments of public health officials have significantly declined among Republicans since March [9, 10]. A survey shows that 72% of Democrats and those who lean to the party say public health officials are doing well, which has remained relatively stable since March (74%) [7, 10]. However, only about half of Republicans (53%) give positive ratings to public health officials, marking a 31-point decrease since late March (84%) [10].
![Public health officials' ratings by party affiliation over time.](image2)

In March, 84% of Republicans rated public health officials positively, which fell to 53% by August. Democrats' views remained largely unchanged, with 74% in March and 72% in August rating them positively [2].
![COVID-19 response ratings for various officials.](image8)

Regarding Donald Trump, his ratings for the response to the outbreak are lower than in March [5]. The partisan difference is stark: 82% of Democrats rate Trump's response as "poor," a steep increase from 56% in March [3]. Conversely, Republicans' approval of Trump's response has increased, although his overall approval ratings have decreased since March [5].
![Approval ratings for Donald Trump by party affiliation.](image6)

Democrats are much less likely than Republicans to approve, with 93% disapproval for Democrats and only 20% for Republicans.

In conclusion, partisan differences significantly shape perceptions of the COVID-19 response, with Democrats generally favoring public health officials and disapproving of Trump, while Republicans show declining trust in public health officials but increasing approval for Trump.

Public approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased from March to August, with significant partisan differences in these changes.

Overall, positive views of public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have declined from 79% in March to 63% in August [4]. This decline is primarily among Republicans, with their positive ratings dropping from 84% to 53% [1, 12]. Democrats' views have remained relatively stable, at 74% in March and 72% in August [1, 12].
![image7](image7)
This trend is visually represented in the data, which shows a widening gap between Republican and Democratic approval of public health officials over time.

Similarly, Trump's overall approval rating for his response to the coronavirus has declined from the early weeks of the outbreak [9, 10]. Currently, 37% say he is doing an excellent or good job, while 63% say he is doing only a fair or poor job [10]. This is reflected in the data.
![image5](image5)

Partisan differences are stark in Trump's ratings. 77% of Republicans approve of his performance, compared to only 5% of Democrats [2]. The share of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" has risen significantly, from 56% in March to 82% in August [8].
![image4](image4)

In summary, approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have decreased from March to August, driven largely by a significant drop in approval among Republicans, while Democrats' views have remained relatively stable or, in the case of Trump's performance, become significantly more negative.

Americans hold differing views on the COVID-19 response by state governments compared to President Trump's handling of the pandemic. Positive evaluations of state government officials' responses have declined since March, from 70% to 56% [8].

However, a majority of U.S. adults (69%) are more concerned that state governments lifted restrictions too quickly, as opposed to only 30% who believe states were too slow [2].
![69% of people think state governments lifted coronavirus restrictions too quickly.](image1)

In contrast, Americans are highly critical of Trump's response. Nearly half of Americans (48%) rated his response as "poor," an increase of 16 points since March [9].
![48% think Donald Trumps response to the coronavirus outbreak was poor.](image8)
Overall, American's hold more critical views of federal government than that of state government.
